Small cell carcinoma

2 Types of Endometrial Cancers.text: Type I (usually low-grade cancers)Comprise EMACA and other low-grade carcinomas (e.g., mucinous)Arise on basis of unopposed estrogen stimulation (unopposed exogenous or endogenous estrogen, anovulation, polycystic ovaries, obesity)Precursor lesions are hyperplasias due to increased estrogensGenetic abnormalities (microsatellite instability,PTENandKRASmutations, nuclear accumulation of β-catenin)

Precursor lesions are hyperplasias due to increased estrogens
Genetic abnormalities (microsatellite instability,PTENandKRASmutations, nuclear accumulation of β-catenin)

2 Types of Endometrial Cancers.text: Type II (high-grade cancers)Comprise serous carcinoma, CCC, MMMT, UCAEnvironmental exposure (radiation, tamoxifen therapy) (HGSCA, CCC)Hereditary predisposition (BRCA1/BRCA2mutations and Lynch syndrome) (UCA)Typically not associated with unopposed estrogen; hence, atrophic endometrium
sub_points: Comprise serous carcinoma, CCC, MMMT, UCA

2 Types of Endometrial Cancers.text: Recent studies, however, have shown significant heterogeneity within and overlap between type I and II cancers10-19% of EMACAs are high grade and have clinicopathologic and molecular features that are in between type I and II, or are more similar to type II
sub_points: 10-19% of EMACAs are high grade and have clinicopathologic and molecular features that are in between type I and II, or are more similar to type II

2 Types of Endometrial Cancers.text: Although this 2-type classification has been useful to provide framework for understanding pathogenesis of endometrial cancer, it does not completely encompass diversity and heterogeneity of endometrial cancers
Additionally, recent molecular studies have stratified endometrial cancers into 4 genomic types

Presentation.text: Both types present with postmenopausal bleeding &/or serosanguineous vaginal discharge

Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy ± lymph node dissection (depending on grade and other adverse factors)

Prognosis.text: Low-grade: Generally good prognosis unless late stage
High-grade: Generally poorer prognosis, as they often present at later stage and are more aggressive

Cellularity.text: Type I: Usually low cellularity
Type II: Generally more cellular, as cells are more abundant and dyshesive

sub_points: Thus, distinction from endocervical primary may be difficult

Endocervical Primary.text: Use immunohistochemistry (IHC) to distinguish in difficult cases or in younger women with lower uterine segment primary

Extrauterine Primary.text: Few cells and absent diathesis (unless direct extension) or metastasis; history is usually available
Morphology different from usual endometrial types

Arias-Stella Reaction.text: Rare cells seen in pregnancy or on high-dose Provera

Polyps.text: Can rarely be problematic if directly sampled or infarcted and shed very atypical cells with broken-down blood and fibrin

Endometrial Hyperplasia.text: Low cellularity of normal or mildly atypical endometrial cells

Menstrual Endometrium.text: Problematic in perimenopausal women when last menstrual period is unknown
Cell blocks on liquid-based specimens and IHC can help

Directly Sampled Endometrium/Endometrios.text: Can resemble endocervical or endometrial primary
Tubular glands and stroma are giveaway
IHC on cell blocks is helpful in difficult cases

IUD Cells.text: Rare cells with "bubblegum" cytoplasm, history of IUD

Atypical Repair.text: Flat sheets with distinct cell borders and round regular nuclei and nucleoli

Atrophy/Bare Nuclei.text: Pseudodiathesis of atrophic vaginitis is trap
Bland nuclei with no nucleoli or degenerate vacuoles

Small Cell Carcinoma.text: Hypercellularity, diathesis, nuclear molding, small or absent nucleoli, neuroendocrine chromatin, HPV(+)

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Pap test is screening test for cervical squamous carcinoma and its precursors
Endometrial cancers may be inadvertently picked up due to cells being shed
Most patients symptomatic/bleed at presentation
Gynecologists do not rely on Paps for endometrial cancers

HPV and Other Molecular Testing in Gynec.name: HPV and Other Molecular Testing in Gynecologic Cytology

Biology and Epidemiology.text: Nonenveloped, double-stranded DNA viruses of ~ 7,900 base pairs
Most common sexually transmitted disease worldwide
Fundamental cause of cervical cancer in essentially all casesAlso important in other anogenital sites and in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma
sub_points: Also important in other anogenital sites and in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma

Biology and Epidemiology.text: Spread by direct contact, usually sexually transmitted in anogenital sites
> 100 known types differentiated byL1gene that encodes viral capsid
E6andE7are other key genes that inhibit apoptosis to facilitate viral survival by blocking Rb, p53, and p21, leading to carcinogenesis
Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) is human papillomavirus (HPV) viral cytopathic effect and corresponds to production of viral particles
High-risk HPV types can be incorporated into host genome and may result in high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion or carcinoma

Testing.text: Residual fluid from liquid-based Pap tests can be used for molecular testing to detect HPVNoncytologic collection kits can also be used, including self-collection kitsSelf-collection kits may be key to expanding cervical cancer screening to countries without well-established cytologic screening programFDA approval is important for acceptance of molecular testing in USA, though in other countries less regulation is in place
sub_points: Noncytologic collection kits can also be used, including self-collection kitsSelf-collection kits may be key to expanding cervical cancer screening to countries without well-established cytologic screening program
Self-collection kits may be key to expanding cervical cancer screening to countries without well-established cytologic screening program
FDA approval is important for acceptance of molecular testing in USA, though in other countries less regulation is in place

Testing.text: Target amplification methodsPCR (Cobas and Onclarity)Segments of DNA are repeatedly copied and recopied by polymerase enzymes to produce large numbers of target genetic sequenceRequires temperature cycling to create new copies at lower temperature then release them for recopying at higher temperatureRNA can be detected by PCR if reverse transcription is used first to convert RNA into DNAFluorescent molecules can be used to monitor production of copies for quantitationNucleic acid sequence-based amplification (PreTect, HPV Proofer, and NucliSENS EasyQ)Uses reverse transcription to create DNA copy of target RNA followed by selective degradation of RNA and creation of double-stranded DNA from DNA copyDouble-stranded DNA is transcribed into numerous copies of RNA, each of which can then be converted to DNA and then to more RNA, resulting in amplificationHas advantage of being able to proceed at fixed temperature, unlike PCRTranscription-mediated amplification (TMA)(Aptima)Target RNA is captured by complementary oligomers attached to magnetic particleMagnetization of specimen captures RNA and allows for removal of extraneous nucleic acidsReverse transcription of magnet-captured RNA creates DNA that is copied and recopiedDNA copies bind to chemiluminescent probes and are detected by luminometerThese methods offer high sensitivityProduce many copies of target that can contaminate laboratory and lead to false-positive resultsNewer, highly automated versions require less technical skill and reduce contamination problemsFalse-positives still occur due to carry-over between vialsFalse-negative results are less rare than commonly assumed, due to causes includingInterfering substances (blood, lubricants, antifungal creams, etc.)Scant infected cellsLow copy numbers of HPV in cells; this phenomenon is observed in significant fraction of invasive squamous cell carcinomas
sub_points: PCR (Cobas and Onclarity)Segments of DNA are repeatedly copied and recopied by polymerase enzymes to produce large numbers of target genetic sequenceRequires temperature cycling to create new copies at lower temperature then release them for recopying at higher temperatureRNA can be detected by PCR if reverse transcription is used first to convert RNA into DNAFluorescent molecules can be used to monitor production of copies for quantitation
Segments of DNA are repeatedly copied and recopied by polymerase enzymes to produce large numbers of target genetic sequence
Requires temperature cycling to create new copies at lower temperature then release them for recopying at higher temperature

Nucleic acid sequence-based amplification (PreTect, HPV Proofer, and NucliSENS EasyQ)Uses reverse transcription to create DNA copy of target RNA followed by selective degradation of RNA and creation of double-stranded DNA from DNA copyDouble-stranded DNA is transcribed into numerous copies of RNA, each of which can then be converted to DNA and then to more RNA, resulting in amplificationHas advantage of being able to proceed at fixed temperature, unlike PCR

Double-stranded DNA is transcribed into numerous copies of RNA, each of which can then be converted to DNA and then to more RNA, resulting in amplification
Has advantage of being able to proceed at fixed temperature, unlike PCR

Transcription-mediated amplification (TMA)(Aptima)Target RNA is captured by complementary oligomers attached to magnetic particleMagnetization of specimen captures RNA and allows for removal of extraneous nucleic acidsReverse transcription of magnet-captured RNA creates DNA that is copied and recopiedDNA copies bind to chemiluminescent probes and are detected by luminometer
Target RNA is captured by complementary oligomers attached to magnetic particle
Magnetization of specimen captures RNA and allows for removal of extraneous nucleic acids
Reverse transcription of magnet-captured RNA creates DNA that is copied and recopied
DNA copies bind to chemiluminescent probes and are detected by luminometer
These methods offer high sensitivity
Produce many copies of target that can contaminate laboratory and lead to false-positive results
Newer, highly automated versions require less technical skill and reduce contamination problemsFalse-positives still occur due to carry-over between vials
False-positives still occur due to carry-over between vials

Scant infected cells

Testing.text: Signal amplification methodsHybrid capture technique (Hybrid Capture II)Target DNA attaches to HPV type-specific RNA probesAntibodies against DNA-RNA hybrids, attached to microplate wells, capture targets and allow for removal of extraneous DNAProbes directed against DNA-RNA hybrids with attached alkaline phosphatase enzymes then indicate presence of target by reacting with chemiluminescent substratesEach captured DNA therefore results in release of many chemiluminescent signalsInvader technique (Cervista)Overlapping probes target HPV DNA, resulting in segment that cannot bind and is cleavedMany such cleaved segments result from binding to each targetEach of these segments can then combine with multiple fluorescence resonance energy transfer cassettes, resulting in fluorescent signalSignal amplification does not result in increased target nucleic acids, eliminating contamination problemDuring early years of HPV testing, Hybrid Capture technique offered combination of ease of use and FDA approval that led to its widespread adoptionHybrid Capture II has been replaced by newer technologies, but is still important as benchmark

Target DNA attaches to HPV type-specific RNA probes

Invader technique (Cervista)Overlapping probes target HPV DNA, resulting in segment that cannot bind and is cleavedMany such cleaved segments result from binding to each targetEach of these segments can then combine with multiple fluorescence resonance energy transfer cassettes, resulting in fluorescent signal

Specimen Types in Respiratory Cytology a.name: Specimen Types in Respiratory Cytology and Adequacy Criteria

Definitions.text: SputumCoughed-up lung fluids expectorated by patient either from spontaneous bronchial mucus or from mucus induced by inhaled vapors
sub_points: Coughed-up lung fluids expectorated by patient either from spontaneous bronchial mucus or from mucus induced by inhaled vapors

sub_points: Lavage fluid (100-300 mL) collected from alveolated lung parenchyma via bronchoscope wedged into subsegmental bronchus

Definitions.text: Bronchial brushingBronchial mucosa directly brushed during bronchoscopy
sub_points: Bronchial mucosa directly brushed during bronchoscopy

Definitions.text: Bronchial washingLavage fluid (3-5 mL) collected from area of bronchus
sub_points: Lavage fluid (3-5 mL) collected from area of bronchus

sub_points: Sampling from mass lesion using small-bore needle

sub_points: Performed under CT or ultrasound guidance using trocar
Touch preparations allow for cytologic analysis of cells exfoliated from core biopsy

Definitions.text: Navigation bronchoscopyUses machine-assisted guidance to sample mass lesion in lung localized by corresponding radiologic scanMay be performed for lesions too peripheral to be accessed by transbronchial techniques
sub_points: Uses machine-assisted guidance to sample mass lesion in lung localized by corresponding radiologic scan

Cancer Screening.text: Sputum cytology in conjunction with chest x-ray failed as screening test for lung carcinoma

Tuberculosis Screening.text: Sputum and bronchoscopic specimens are often collected in resource-limited world to rule out organisms, especially mycobacteria

Imaging Findings.text: Central lesions, including lymph nodes, are accessible by bronchoscopy
More peripheral lesions may be detected by BAL but usually require percutaneous CT-guided biopsy or navigation bronchoscopy

sub_points: Fresh sputum can be analyzed by pick-and-smear method

Low-power architecture in histology is usually very helpful to differentiate injury responses from malignancy

Adenocarcinoma.text: Features of reactive bronchial cells or type II pneumocytes extensively overlap with adenocarcinoma

Squamous Cell Carcinoma.text: Reactive squamous cells may mimic carcinoma

sub_points: Great care must be taken to avoid false-positives

Reactive cells typically have pale nuclei with less chromatin clumping than malignant cells
Beware of malignancy diagnosis if cilia or terminal bars are present in association with concerning cells
Basal cell hyperplasia can be distinguished from small cell carcinoma by very small cell size and tight clustering
Creola bodies can be recognized by analysis of relatively well-visualized cells at edge, which may have cilia

Clinical Issues.text: Associated with immune dysfunction, especially HIV/AIDS
Favorable prognosis when appropriately treated
Screening forPneumocystisoccurs in setting of lung transplantation and in patients with pneumonia not responding to usual therapy
Among HIV-infected patients, those with CD4 counts < 200 cells/μL are 5x more likely to developPneumocystispneumonia (PCP)
PCR-based molecular testing for PCP has been developed, but since many people are asymptomatic carriers, this methodology is limited by false-positives

Increased inflammation and possibly giant cells may be seen in background

Definitions.text: Clinically significant lung infection caused by fungusPneumocystis jiroveci(formerlyPneumocystis carinii)

Presentation.text: Associated with immune dysfunction, especially HIV/AIDS
Screening forPneumocystisoccurs in setting of lung transplantation and in patients with pneumonia not responding to usual therapy

Laboratory Tests.text: Among HIV-infected patients, those with CD4 counts < 200 cells/μL are 5x more likely to develop PCP
PCR-based molecular testing for PCP has been developed, but since many people are asymptomatic carriers, this methodology is limited by false-positives

Natural History.text: Infection is acquired by inhalation with primary infection occurring early in life and remaining latent
Favorable prognosis when appropriately treated

Radiographic Findings.text: Ground-glass perihilar or diffuse bilateral airspace consolidation

Pattern.text: Alveolar casts of fluffy debris

Background.text: Increased inflammation and possibly giant cells

Cells.text: On conventional stains, organisms appear as numerous refractile clear discs (4-7 μm) embedded in clumped amorphous material
GMS stain highlights cyst organisms with collapsed ovoid morphology and prominent central dot
Organisms show characteristic "coffee cup" or "crushed ping pong ball" morphology
Diff-Quik/Romanowsky stains demonstrate central dot but not organism outline

Cytology-Histology Correlation.text: Cytology is more sensitive for detection of organisms

Histologic Features.text: Typical pattern is characterized by foamy, granular eosinophilic intraalveolar exudates containing organisms

Other Fungal Infections.text: Histoplasma capsulatummay show similar morphology toPneumocystis, including central dark dots
Cryptococcus neoformansmay also resemblePneumocystiswith collapsed ovoid forms
Mimicking fungi may be intracellular or lack alveolar casts and will show budding yeast forms

Alveolar Proteinosis.text: Though clinically very different, bothPneumocystisand alveolar proteinosis show alveolar casts in lavage specimens
Alveolar proteinosis lacks organisms, casts stain with PAS

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Alveolar casts are distinctive, and refractile organisms can be seen on high power with conventional stains

GMS stains facilitate diagnosis and are helpful for identifying rare organisms in low-level infectionsOrganisms have characteristic central dot and "coffee cup" or "crushed ping pong ball" morphology when viewed from side angle
sub_points: Organisms have characteristic central dot and "coffee cup" or "crushed ping pong ball" morphology when viewed from side angle

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: AIDS, transplantation, or chemotherapy predispose to severe infections

sub_points: Many less common fungi not ofAspergillusgenus may have identical morphology

Candidaspecies, usually contaminants in lung specimens, have yeast or pseudohyphal forms
Major infectious yeasts includeCryptococcus,Histoplasma, andBlastomycesThese can often be differentiated by size, shape, budding pattern, and encapsulation
sub_points: These can often be differentiated by size, shape, budding pattern, and encapsulation

Cytopathology.text: Less common yeasts includeCoccidioides,Paracoccidioides,Talaromyces,Emmonsia,Emergomyces, andSporothrix

Ancillary Tests.text: GMS and PAS improve sensitivity and morphologic characterization
Mucicarmine highlights capsule ofCryptococcus

Vegetable matter, fibers, and foreign body particles can be confused with fungal forms
Pneumocystisis now recognized as fungus but is generally considered separately

Definitions.text: Infection or colonization of lung by fungal organisms

Immunosuppression.text: AIDS, transplantation, or chemotherapy predispose to severe infections

Presentation.text: Ranges from incidental finding to life-threatening pneumonia
Aspergillusmay present as allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, chronic pulmonary aspergillosis (including fungus balls in cavitary lesions), or as invasive aspergillosis

Treatment.text: Itraconazole, fluconazole, and related antifungals

AspergillusSpecies and Mimics.text: Septate straight-edged hyphae (3-6 μm) with acute angle branching
Rarely, fruiting bodies in cavity-filling aspergillomas
Many fungi may have same appearance asAspergillus

Zygomyces/MucorSpecies.text: Ribbon-like, wavy-edged, nonseptate hyphae (4-15 μm) with right angle branching
Often empty appearance due to spillage of organelles

CandidaSpecies.text: Yeasts and pseudohyphae often seen in association with oral squamous cells and bacteria

Dimorphic Fungi.text: Cryptococcusis more variable in size than other yeasts
Blastomycescan be distinguished by broad-based budding and thick walls
Large spherules inCoccidioides(with endospores),Paracoccidioides(with budding), andEmmonsia

Histochemistry.text: GMS or PAS highlights fungal forms

Microbiology Laboratory.text: Antigen tests, culture, and PCR provide greater sensitivity and specificity than cytology

Extraneous Debris.text: Vegetable matter, fibers, and foreign body particles

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Hyphal organisms can be divided intoAspergillus-like andMucor-like categories, but morphology alone is not very reliable for differentiating
Yeast forms can often be specifically identified on basis of morphology

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Protozoa (Toxoplasma,Cryptosporidium, microsporidia,Entamoeba), nematodes (Strongyloides,Dirofilaria, microfilaria), cestodes (Echinococcus), and trematodes (Paragonimus,Schistosoma)

Clinical Issues.text: Parasites numerous enough to be identified in cytology specimens are usually associated with immunosuppression
Strongyloidesmay be seen in massive numbers in patients with hyperinfection, often associated with steroid treatment
Disseminated toxoplasmosis is typically associated with AIDS or stem cell/organ transplantation

Cytopathology.text: Strongyloidesfilariform larvae (0.2 mm in length) have short, pointed tails and no sheath
FNA of hydatid cyst may include characteristic protoscolices and hooklets, but biopsy is rarely performed due to risk of rupture
CharacteristicParagonimusorSchistosomaeggs may appear in sputum or FNA of granulomatous lesions
Toxoplasmamay be identified as free-living, crescent-shaped tachyzoites (5 μm) &/or bradyzoites (2 μm) within pseudocysts (10-50 μm)

Ancillary Tests.text: GMS, PAS, Giemsa, or trichrome may help to identify protozoans

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Vegetable matter, fibers, and other exogenous elements may simulate parasitic forms
Fungal yeasts may resemble protozoans
Dirofilarial infarcts and granulomas caused by other protozoans may raise concern for malignancy by radiology

Definitions.text: Infection of lung by parasitic organisms

Lung Parasites.text: Protozoa (Toxoplasma,Cryptosporidium, microsporidia,Entamoeba), nematodes (Strongyloides,Dirofilaria, microfilaria), cestodes (Echinococcus), and trematodes (Paragonimus,Schistosoma)

Presentation.text: Parasites numerous enough to be identified in cytology specimens are usually associated with pneumonia in immunocompromised individualsNumerousStrongyloidesworms are seen in patients with hyperinfection, often due to steroid treatmentDisseminated toxoplasmosis is typically associated with AIDS or stem cell/organ transplantation
sub_points: NumerousStrongyloidesworms are seen in patients with hyperinfection, often due to steroid treatment
Disseminated toxoplasmosis is typically associated with AIDS or stem cell/organ transplantation

Presentation.text: Some parasites cause localized inflammatory or granulomatous reactionDirofilariacauses infarcts that look like tumors by radiologyParagonimus,Schistosoma, orEchinococcusmay also cause mass lesions
sub_points: Dirofilariacauses infarcts that look like tumors by radiology
Paragonimus,Schistosoma, orEchinococcusmay also cause mass lesions

Drugs.text: Ivermectin, albendazole, and other related agents

Strongyloides stercoralis(Threadworm).text: Filariform larvae (0.2 mm in length) have short, pointed tails and no sheath

Dirofilaria immitis(Dog Heartworm).text: Organisms rarely seen in cytology, but FNA biopsies of lesions yield necrotic debris that may mimic malignancy

EchinococcusSpecies (Hydatid Disease).text: FNA of hydatid cyst may include characteristic protoscolices and hooklets, but biopsy is rarely performed due to risk of rupture

ParagonimusandSchistosomaSpecies.text: Characteristic eggs may appear in sputum or FNA of granulomatous lesions

Toxoplasma gondii.text: Free-living, crescent-shaped tachyzoites (5 μm) &/or bradyzoites (2 μm) within pseudocysts (10-50 μm)

Entamoeba histolytica.text: Trophozoites (10-50 μm) resemble large histiocytes but with small, round nuclei containing karyosomes

Special Stains.text: GMS, PAS, Giemsa, or trichrome may help identify protozoans

Laboratory Tests.text: PCR, serology, and examination of stool for parasites and eggs

Debris.text: Vegetable matter, fibers, and other exogenous elements may simulate parasitic forms

Malignancy.text: Parasites, such asDirofilaria,Paragonimus,Schistosoma, andEchinococcus, may cause radiologically worrisome mass lesion

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Reproduce within cells, causing injury to pulmonary tissues
Frequently associated with immunosuppression that allows virus to flourish
Many common lung viruses, including influenza, parainfluenza, rhinovirus, and coronavirus, do not have distinctive cytologic findings

Clinical Issues.text: Presents as bronchitis or pneumonia
Acyclovir, ganciclovir, and related medications may be useful
To degree possible, reversal of drug-related immunosuppression may also lead to improvement

Cytopathology.text: Common lung viruses with identifiable cytopathic effect include cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpesvirusCMV produces nuclear enlargement with prominent intranuclear inclusion and marginated chromatinHerpesvirus shows triad of multinucleation, margination, and molding
sub_points: CMV produces nuclear enlargement with prominent intranuclear inclusion and marginated chromatin
Herpesvirus shows triad of multinucleation, margination, and molding

Cytopathology.text: Other viruses that may involve lung and be identified by cytology include adenovirus, respiratory syncytial virus, and measlesConsider other viruses when nuclear enlargement and homogenization are seen without typical CMV or herpes features
sub_points: Consider other viruses when nuclear enlargement and homogenization are seen without typical CMV or herpes features

Ancillary Tests.text: CMV, herpesvirus, and adenovirus have specific immunohistochemical stains
PCR and serology are alternate methods of detection that may be faster and more sensitive

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Nuclear changes due to inflammation or cytotoxic therapy may mimic viral cytopathic effect

Definitions.text: Pulmonary infection by viral pathogen

Viral Pathogens.text: Reproduce within cells, causing injury to pulmonary tissues
Frequently associated with immunosuppression that allows virus to flourish
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) and herpes simplex virus, and related DNA viruses of herpesvirus family, are most commonly identified viruses in lung cytology specimens
Other viruses that may involve lung, and be identified by cytology include adenovirus, respiratory syncytial virus, and measles virus
Many common lung viruses, including influenza, parainfluenza, rhinovirus, and coronavirus (including COVID-19), do not have distinctive cytologic findings

Presentation.text: Bronchitis or pneumonia

Treatment.text: Acyclovir, ganciclovir, and related antiviral medications
Reversal of immunosuppression to some degree possible

Prognosis.text: Outcomes depend on extent of infection and severity of comorbid conditions

Background.text: Increased inflammation and necrotic debris may be noticeable

Cells.text: Viral cytopathic effect may be seen in bronchial cells, pneumocytes, or giant cells

Nuclear Details.text: CMV produces nuclear enlargement with prominent intranuclear inclusion and marginated chromatin (Cowdry type A body); can also have fine, granular cytoplasmic inclusions
Herpesvirus (simplex and zoster) has homogenized nuclei that may also contain central inclusion and shows triad of multinucleation, margination, and molding
Adenovirus produces nuclear enlargement and may have either multiple small inclusions in early stages, or single large inclusion with nuclear margination when fully developed
Measles virus produces red inclusions in nucleus and cytoplasm

Cytoplasmic Details.text: Measles virus and respiratory syncytial virus are associated with cytoplasmic inclusions in giant cells

Immunohistochemistry.text: CMV, herpesvirus, and adenovirus have specific immunohistochemical stains

Reactive Changes.text: Nuclear changes due to inflammation or cytotoxic therapy may mimic viral cytopathic effect

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Viral cytopathic effects may have overlapping morphology, especially if only few cells are seen
Viruses in lung are similar in appearance to same viruses seen in other parts of body

Clinical Issues.text: Mycobacterium tuberculosispresents as granulomas
Nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) are most often members ofMycobacterium aviumcomplex (MAC) and present as cavitary or nodular/bronchiectatic disease, usually in setting of immune deficiency
Uncommon bacteria, includingNocardiaandRhodococcus, may also present in manner similar to NTM, especially in immunocompromised patients
Other, more common bacteria typically present with pneumonia

Cytopathology.text: Necrotic debris is present in many bacterial infections
Granulomatous inflammation is characterized by epithelioid histiocytes and giant cells
Acute inflammation manifests as numerous neutrophils
Reactive bronchial cells &/or type II pneumocytes are frequently present
Histiocytes have round, bean-shaped, or twisted nuclei with dispersed chromatin
Histiocytic aggregates form syncytium without clear cytoplasmic borders

Ancillary Tests.text: Acid-fast stains enhance detection of mycobacterial organisms but low sensitivity compared with molecular methods or culture

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Other infections
Other noninfectious granulomasSarcoidosis, rheumatoid nodules, and foreign body reactions may look similar to tuberculosis
sub_points: Sarcoidosis, rheumatoid nodules, and foreign body reactions may look similar to tuberculosis

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: MalignancyReactive cells, epithelioid histiocytes, and necrotic debris may raise concern for malignancy
sub_points: Reactive cells, epithelioid histiocytes, and necrotic debris may raise concern for malignancy

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Oral contaminant

Presentation.text: Mycobacterium tuberculosispresents as granulomasMay be localized or disseminated (miliary)Mediastinal node involvement is often present, and there may be broader systemic involvement, especially in immunocompromised patients
sub_points: May be localized or disseminated (miliary)
Mediastinal node involvement is often present, and there may be broader systemic involvement, especially in immunocompromised patients

Presentation.text: Nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) are most often members ofMycobacterium aviumcomplex (MAC)May present as cavitary or nodular/bronchiectatic disease, usually in setting of immune deficiencySome NTM organisms may cause hypersensitivity reaction rather than infection
sub_points: May present as cavitary or nodular/bronchiectatic disease, usually in setting of immune deficiency
Some NTM organisms may cause hypersensitivity reaction rather than infection

Presentation.text: Uncommon bacteria, includingNocardiaandRhodococcus, may also present in manner similar to NTM, especially in immunocompromised patients
Other, more common bacteria typically present with pneumonia

Background.text: Necrotic debris is present in many bacterial infections

Cells.text: Granulomatous inflammation is characterized by epithelioid histiocytes and giant cells
Acute inflammation manifests as numerous neutrophils
Reactive bronchial cells &/or type II pneumocytes are frequently present

Nuclear Details.text: Histiocytes have round, bean-shaped, or twisted nuclei with dispersed chromatin

Cytoplasmic Details.text: Histiocytic aggregates form syncytium without clear cytoplasmic borders

Acid-Fast Stains.text: Routinely performed to enhance detection of mycobacterial organisms but low sensitivity

Other Microscopy Techniques.text: Fluorescent or light-emitting diode microscopy can increase sensitivity for mycobacteria relative to acid-fast staining

Nonmicroscopic Techniques.text: Sensitive, rapid, and easy-to-use techniques are needed to facilitate diagnosis in low-resource countries
Molecular and immunologic detection kits for tuberculosis are commercially available but still suboptimalMany new technologies are being developed
sub_points: Many new technologies are being developed

Nonmicroscopic Techniques.text: Screening in HIV(+) or otherwise immune-suppressed people and in children is especially problematic

Culture.text: Gold standard method but technically difficult and slow for many organisms, including mycobacteria

Other Infections.text: Bacterial infections have similar cytologic features to many viral, fungal, and parasitic infections
Specifically identifiable organisms are less commonly seen in bacterial infections

Other Noninfectious Granulomas.text: Sarcoidosis, rheumatoid nodules, and foreign body reactions may look similar to tuberculosis

Malignancy.text: Reactive cells, epithelioid histiocytes, and necrotic debris may raise concern for malignancy

Oral Contaminant.text: Most bacteria seen in lung specimens are oral contaminants with no clinical significance

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Only small fraction of granulomas are due to tuberculosis
Acid-fast staining is frequently negative in culture-positive mycobacterial disease

Clinical Issues.text: Sarcoidosis is idiopathic granulomatous disease often involving lung and mediastinum
Rheumatoid nodules may form in lung or pleura
Eosinophilic pneumonia is diagnosed by presence of markedly increased eosinophils in right clinical setting
Lung manifestations often reflect only 1 aspect of systemic disease

Cytopathology.text: Multinucleated giant cells and epithelioid histiocyte aggregates are typical of sarcoidosisNecrotic debris usually rare or absent
sub_points: Necrotic debris usually rare or absent

Cytopathology.text: Rheumatoid nodules may shed abundant necrotic debris, histiocytes, and giant cellsHistiocytes may have nuclear atypia or keratin-like orangophilic staining, raising concern for malignancy
sub_points: Histiocytes may have nuclear atypia or keratin-like orangophilic staining, raising concern for malignancy

Cytopathology.text: Eosinophilic pneumonia shows predominance of eosinophils and may have Charcot-Leyden crystals

Giant cells may contain asteroid bodies, Schaumann bodies (lamellated calcifications around calcium oxalate), or Hamazaki-Wesenberg bodies (fungus-like giant lysosomes)None of these are specific for sarcoidosis
sub_points: None of these are specific for sarcoidosis

Ancillary Tests.text: Fungal and mycobacterial stains to rule out organisms are essential in granulomatous diseases
Serum angiotensin-converting enzyme level elevations support diagnosis of sarcoidosis

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Granulomatous inflammation due to infectious etiologies
Other granulomatous responses, including foreign body reaction and response to tumors
Clinical concern for malignancy often arises in context of sarcoidosis due to enlarged mediastinal nodes with high PET values
Necrotic debris and bizarre cells in rheumatoid nodules may simulate malignancy

Sarcoidosis.text: Granulomatous disease of unknown etiology most often involving lung and mediastinum
Diagnosis of exclusion requiring elimination of known infectious and other causes of granuloma formation
Elevated angiotensin-converting enzyme levels in serum may aid diagnosis
Sarcoid-like reaction to tumors, including lung carcinomas, may occur

Other Immune-Related Inflammatory Condit.text: Rheumatoid nodules may form in pleura or less commonly in lung parenchymaRheumatoid arthritis may also produce lung fibrosis
sub_points: Rheumatoid arthritis may also produce lung fibrosis

Other Immune-Related Inflammatory Condit.text: Eosinophilic pneumonia is diagnosed by presence of markedly increased eosinophils in lavage specimensMay be acute, chronic, associated with vasculitis (Churg-Strauss disease) or secondary reaction
sub_points: May be acute, chronic, associated with vasculitis (Churg-Strauss disease) or secondary reaction

Other Immune-Related Inflammatory Condit.text: Other immune-related diseases, such as hypersensitivity pneumonitis, Wegener granulomatosis, and Rosai-Dorfman disease, may involve lung but are very difficult to identify cytologically

Cellularity.text: Immune-related diseases often have increased cellularity due to inflammatory cells

Background.text: Sarcoidosis usually does not have significant necrotic debris
Necrotic debris is seen in many immune-related diseases, notably rheumatoid nodules

Cells.text: Multinucleated giant cells and epithelioid histiocyte aggregates are typical of sarcoidosis
Rheumatoid nodules also contain histiocytes and giant cells
Numerous eosinophils characterize eosinophilic pneumonia

Nuclear Details.text: Epithelioid histiocytes have elongated irregular nuclei with indistinct nucleoliHyperchromasia may be present
sub_points: Hyperchromasia may be present

Cytoplasmic Details.text: Giant cells may contain asteroid bodies, Schaumann bodies (lamellated calcifications around calcium oxalate), or Hamazaki-Wesenberg bodies (fungus-like giant lysosomes)None of these are specific for sarcoidosis
sub_points: None of these are specific for sarcoidosis

Cytoplasmic Details.text: Epithelioid histiocytes may have degenerative orangeophilia of cytoplasm mimicking keratinizationThis change is especially prevalent in rheumatoid nodules
sub_points: This change is especially prevalent in rheumatoid nodules

Histologic Features.text: Sarcoidosis is typified by small, nonnecrotizing granulomas with lymphangitic distribution

Granulomatous Inflammation Due to Infect.text: Fungal and mycobacterial stains &/or cultures or PCR are needed to rule out organisms

Other Granulomatous Responses.text: Foreign bodies and tumors may incite giant cell reactions

Malignancy.text: Sarcoidosis often produces enlarged mediastinal nodes with high PET values
Necrotic debris and bizarre cells in rheumatoid nodules may simulate malignancy

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Giant cells are primary cytologic manifestation of sarcoidosis but are not specific
Marked increases in eosinophils may indicate eosinophilic pneumonia

Clinical Issues.text: Respiratory distress due to alveoli filled with proteinaceous material secondary to macrophage dysfunction or surfactant excess
Usually autoimmune but also seen in association with immunosuppression, hematologic malignancies, inhalational exposures, congenital syndromes
Bronchoalveolar lavage is treatment modality

Imaging.text: CT finding of crazy-paving patten with ground-glass opacities and thickened septa is distinctive

Cytopathology.text: Globular homogeneous structures
Abundant proteinaceous material in background
Alveolar macrophages also contain proteinaceous debris in cytoplasmic vacuoles

Macroscopic.text: Lavage fluid is milky and settles into layers

Ancillary Tests.text: PAS-D
Serum testing for GM-CSF autoantibody

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Pneumocystispneumonia"Foamy" alveolar casts with GMS-positive organisms
sub_points: "Foamy" alveolar casts with GMS-positive organisms

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: NecrosisDebris without distinct globules, associated with inflammatory or malignant cells
sub_points: Debris without distinct globules, associated with inflammatory or malignant cells

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Corpora amylaceaUsually few in number, weakly polarizable glycoprotein globules
sub_points: Usually few in number, weakly polarizable glycoprotein globules

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Amyloid
Amiodarone toxicity

Definitions.text: Nonneoplastic condition in which alveoli are filled with proteinaceous material

Etiology.text: Result of macrophage dysfunction or surfactant excess
Usually autoimmune, due to formation of GM-CSF antibodies
Can also be seen in association with immunosuppression, hematologic malignancies, inhalational exposures, rare congenital syndromes

Treatment.text: Bronchoalveolar lavage
Immune modulation with GM-CSF administration or rituximab

General Features.text: CT finding of crazy-paving patten with ground-glass opacities and thickened septa is distinctiveNot entirely sensitive or specific
sub_points: Not entirely sensitive or specific

Cellularity.text: Low cellularity due to protein excess

Background.text: Proteinaceous materialGlobular homogeneous structuresAlcohol fixation enhances this appearanceScattered granular debris
sub_points: Globular homogeneous structuresAlcohol fixation enhances this appearance
Alcohol fixation enhances this appearance
Scattered granular debris

Cells.text: Alveolar macrophages also contain proteinaceous debris

General Features.text: Congested lung parenchyma with yellow tinge

Histologic Features.text: Alveolar filling by granular proteinaceous material with preservation of alveolar architecture

Necrosis.text: No distinct globules; inflammatory or tumor cells

Corpora Amylacea.text: Glycoprotein globules with faint concentric rings, positive for PAS, weakly polarizable, usually few in number

Amyloid.text: Rarely forms distinct globules, positive for Congo red birefringence

Amiodarone Toxicity.text: Lamellated inclusions in macrophages, lacks globules

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Gross appearanceLavage fluid is milkySettles into layers
sub_points: Lavage fluid is milky
Settles into layers

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: PAS staining is diastase resistant and will highlight proteinaceous material

Clinical Issues.text: Variable presentation: Incidental "coin" lesion to widespread metastasis
Curable by surgery if low stage but poor prognosis for most patients

Cytopathology.text: Prominent nucleoli are common
Lepidic pattern carcinomas show nuclear grooves and pseudoinclusions
Poorly differentiated carcinomas have marked anisonucleosis and pleomorphism
Intracytoplasmic mucin is diagnosticMay be in small vacuoles or single large vacuole
sub_points: May be in small vacuoles or single large vacuole

Cytopathology.text: Abundant foamy cytoplasm is typical

Ancillary Tests.text: TTF-1 or napsin A to differentiate from squamous cell carcinoma or metastasisBoth are negative in ~ 20% of cases
sub_points: Both are negative in ~ 20% of cases

Ancillary Tests.text: Molecular testing for mutation-specific chemotherapy
PD-L1 for targeted immunotherapy

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Squamous cell carcinomaIf morphology and immunohistochemistry are inconclusive, diagnose as non-small cell carcinoma, not otherwise specified
sub_points: If morphology and immunohistochemistry are inconclusive, diagnose as non-small cell carcinoma, not otherwise specified

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Carcinoma in situ and atypical adenomatous hyperplasiaCannot be distinguished from lepidic pattern invasive adenocarcinoma by cytology alone
sub_points: Cannot be distinguished from lepidic pattern invasive adenocarcinoma by cytology alone

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Adenocarcinoma of extrathoracic originClinical and radiologic correlation in conjunction with immunohistochemistry can resolve many, but not all, difficult cases
sub_points: Clinical and radiologic correlation in conjunction with immunohistochemistry can resolve many, but not all, difficult cases

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Reactive changesWell-differentiated adenocarcinoma and reactive changes have overlapping morphologic features
sub_points: Well-differentiated adenocarcinoma and reactive changes have overlapping morphologic features

Definitions.text: Malignant epithelial neoplasm with glandular differentiation

Etiology.text: Tumor probably originates from precursors to bronchial cells and pneumocytes
Often associated with smoking but to lesser degree than other lung cancersMost lung cancers in young people, and in those who have never smoked, are adenocarcinomas
sub_points: Most lung cancers in young people, and in those who have never smoked, are adenocarcinomas

Incidence.text: Lung carcinoma is #1 cause of cancer deaths worldwide (18% of all cancer deaths)#1 cause of cancer death among both men (29%) and women (26%) in USAAccounts for more cases than next 3 leading causes of cancer death (breast, prostate, and colon) combined
sub_points: #1 cause of cancer death among both men (29%) and women (26%) in USA
Accounts for more cases than next 3 leading causes of cancer death (breast, prostate, and colon) combined

Incidence.text: Adenocarcinoma comprises 1/2 of all lung cancers worldwide with highest percentage in East Asia

Presentation.text: Variable: Incidental "coin" lesion to widespread metastasis

Surgical approaches.text: Surgery is indicated for localized tumors with limited metastasisMost tumors present at advanced stage and are inoperable
sub_points: Most tumors present at advanced stage and are inoperable

Surgical approaches.text: Many patients are excluded because they cannot tolerate lost lung volume due to smoking-related chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

Adjuvant therapy.text: New targeted therapies againstEGFR,ALK, andROS1mutations offer dramatic responses with few side effects, at least in short term

Prognosis.text: Curable by surgery if low stage but poor prognosis for most patients
Minority of patients withEGFR,ALK, orROS1mutation can receive targeted therapy with improved prognosis

Cellularity.text: High cellularity is typical but may also be seen in some reactive processes

Pattern.text: Patterns are highly variable and do not correlate well with histologic patterns in most cases
Disaggregated signet-ring cells may be seen, rarely exclusively
Frequent small, round clusters of cells may correspond to micropapillary pattern

Background.text: Necrotic debris may be prominent
Uncommon mucinous, colloid, or enteric adenocarcinomas may have abundant background mucin

Cells.text: When present, large cells, columnar to cuboidal with basal nuclei and apical cytoplasm, are characteristic

Nuclear Details.text: Prominent nucleoli are common
Lepidic pattern adenocarcinomas have uniform nuclei with nuclear grooves and pseudoinclusions
Poorly differentiated carcinomas have marked anisonucleosis and pleomorphism

Cytoplasmic Details.text: Intracytoplasmic mucin is diagnostic
Abundant foamy cytoplasm with numerous small vacuoles is common
Cells may show single prominent vacuole, sometimes compressing nucleus into signet-ring shape
Mucinous tumors have especially abundant apical cytoplasm filled with mucin
Fetal-type adenocarcinoma has subnuclear glycogen vacuoles; squamoid morules may also be seen

General Features.text: Typically peripheral but may be central

Histologic Features.text: Invasive gland-forming or mucin-producing malignant cells
Lepidic pattern adenocarcinoma may be mucinous or nonmucinousMay be in situ or minimally invasive, but complete histologic sampling is needed for confirmation
sub_points: May be in situ or minimally invasive, but complete histologic sampling is needed for confirmation

Histologic Features.text: Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia (AAH): Small lesion (< 0.5 cm) with uniformly atypical cellsThought to be adenocarcinoma precursorRarely sampled by cytology due to small size and lack of symptoms
sub_points: Thought to be adenocarcinoma precursor
Rarely sampled by cytology due to small size and lack of symptoms

Predominant Pattern/Injury Type.text: Multiple morphologic types are recognized by World Health Organization (WHO)Common types include acinar, solid, and lepidicLess common types include papillary, micropapillary, mucinous, colloid, enteric, and fetal
sub_points: Common types include acinar, solid, and lepidic
Less common types include papillary, micropapillary, mucinous, colloid, enteric, and fetal

Histochemistry.text: MucicarmineStaining pattern: Highlights intracellular &/or extracellular mucin
sub_points: Staining pattern: Highlights intracellular &/or extracellular mucin

Immunohistochemistry.text: TTF-1Positive in ~ 80% of lung adenocarcinomasNuclear stainBeware positive TTF-1 in neuroendocrine tumors and metastasis from thyroid or müllerian tract
sub_points: Positive in ~ 80% of lung adenocarcinomas
Nuclear stain
Beware positive TTF-1 in neuroendocrine tumors and metastasis from thyroid or müllerian tract

Immunohistochemistry.text: Napsin AAlso positive in ~ 80% of lung adenocarcinomasGranular cytoplasmic stainingMay be positive in cases that are TTF-1(-), but usually, both are positive or both are negativeDual TTF-1 and napsin A stains are available
sub_points: Also positive in ~ 80% of lung adenocarcinomas
Granular cytoplasmic staining
May be positive in cases that are TTF-1(-), but usually, both are positive or both are negative
Dual TTF-1 and napsin A stains are available

Immunohistochemistry.text: MOC31, Ber-EP4, mCEA, B72.3Numerous immunohistochemistry stains have been proposed to separate adenocarcinoma from epithelioid mesotheliomaNot specific for adenocarcinoma of lung origin
sub_points: Numerous immunohistochemistry stains have been proposed to separate adenocarcinoma from epithelioid mesothelioma
Not specific for adenocarcinoma of lung origin

sub_points: Staining used to determine eligibility for targeted immunotherapyCutoffs vary, but as little as 1% may make patients eligible; report percentage with membranous staining100 tumor cell minimum has been recommended for valid testing, but this is disputed

Distinguishing membranous positivity from nonspecific cytoplasmic staining is more difficult if smears are stained rather than cell blocks

Molecular Testing.text: EGFRfor targeted chemotherapyEGFRmutations present in > 30% of adenocarcinomas in East Asians and ≤ 15% in other populationsNumerous activating gene mutations must be analyzedCan be done by many different sequencing methodsCell block is preferred, but smears may be usedMETamplification testing may be requested in patients with acquired resistance toEGFR-targeted therapy
sub_points: EGFRmutations present in > 30% of adenocarcinomas in East Asians and ≤ 15% in other populations
Numerous activating gene mutations must be analyzed
Can be done by many different sequencing methods
Cell block is preferred, but smears may be used
METamplification testing may be requested in patients with acquired resistance toEGFR-targeted therapy

Molecular Testing.text: ALKfor targeted chemotherapyTranslocation present in only ~ 4% of adenocarcinomasTranslocation involvingEML4andALKDone by fluorescent in situ hybridizationCell block is preferred, but smears may be used
sub_points: Translocation present in only ~ 4% of adenocarcinomas

Molecular Testing.text: ROS1for targeted chemotherapyTranslocation present in 1-2% of adenocarcinomasHomologous toALK, with similar testing, and susceptible to same targeted agents
sub_points: Translocation present in 1-2% of adenocarcinomas
Homologous toALK, with similar testing, and susceptible to same targeted agents

Molecular Testing.text: KRASMost common mutation, not currently targetable; often tested because if present other mutations are excludedTherapies under development targeting G12C mutation
sub_points: Most common mutation, not currently targetable; often tested because if present other mutations are excluded
Therapies under development targeting G12C mutation

Molecular Testing.text: Other less common targetable mutations includeBRAF,ERBB2(HER2),MET,RET, andNTRKMultiplex molecular testing, such as whole-genome analysis, may eventually be needed to identify all relevant mutations in small cytology samples
sub_points: Multiplex molecular testing, such as whole-genome analysis, may eventually be needed to identify all relevant mutations in small cytology samples

Squamous Cell Carcinoma.text: Clear-cut keratinization is diagnostic but often not present
Immunohistochemistry positive for p40, diffuse p63, or CK5/6 supports squamous differentiation

Non-Small Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise.text: Alternate cytology diagnosis for uncommon instances of morphology and immunocytochemistry ambiguous for adenocarcinoma vs. squamous cell carcinoma

Carcinoma In Situ and Atypical Adenomato.text: Indistinguishable from well-differentiated invasive lepidic pattern adenocarcinoma by cytology

Mesothelioma.text: Epithelioid mesothelioma can usually be separated by clinical presentation and immunohistochemistry panels

Salivary Gland-Type Tumors.text: Shows characteristic features of salivary gland analogs
Adenoid cystic carcinoma with basaloid cells and central matrix globules is most common

Pulmonary Blastoma.text: Presence of morules and embryonic-type glandular structures

Adenocarcinoma of Extrathoracic Origin.text: Immunohistochemistry positive for TTF-1 or napsin A strongly supports lung originTTF-1 can be positive in neuroendocrine, thyroid, and müllerian tumors
sub_points: TTF-1 can be positive in neuroendocrine, thyroid, and müllerian tumors

Adenocarcinoma of Extrathoracic Origin.text: Lung adenocarcinoma is typically CK7(+) and CK20(-)Breast, pancreas, stomach, and other sources of metastasis may have same pattern
sub_points: Breast, pancreas, stomach, and other sources of metastasis may have same pattern

Adenocarcinoma of Extrathoracic Origin.text: Enteric adenocarcinomas may be indistinguishable from colorectal carcinomaCK20 and CDX2 may be expressed by enteric adenocarcinoma of lung origin
sub_points: CK20 and CDX2 may be expressed by enteric adenocarcinoma of lung origin

Adenocarcinoma of Extrathoracic Origin.text: Lepidic pattern adenocarcinomas can have nuclear features reminiscent of papillary thyroid carcinomaPAX8 and thyroglobulin can help identify thyroid origin
sub_points: PAX8 and thyroglobulin can help identify thyroid origin

Reactive Changes.text: Well-differentiated adenocarcinoma and reactive changes have overlapping morphologic features

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Age, smoking historyYounger patients and nonsmokers are more likely to have targetable mutations, but all patients should be tested
sub_points: Younger patients and nonsmokers are more likely to have targetable mutations, but all patients should be tested

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Adenocarcinoma has highly variable cytologic features
Common features include marked nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and foamy cytoplasm
Mucin production is diagnostic

Well-differentiated carcinomas, especially lepidic pattern, can be very difficult to distinguish from reactive changesTerm bronchioloalveolar carcinoma has been eliminated due to inconsistent applicationTumors previously characterized as bronchioloalveolar would now be considered lepidic pattern
sub_points: Term bronchioloalveolar carcinoma has been eliminated due to inconsistent application
Tumors previously characterized as bronchioloalveolar would now be considered lepidic pattern

Not Currently Recommended in Cytology.text: Traditional grading techniques have not been demonstrated to have useful clinical implications

Surgical Pathology Grading Depends on Pr.text: Lepidic-predominant are grade 1 if < 20% higher grade pattern
Acinar or papillary-predominant are grade 2 if < 20% grade 3 pattern
Solid, cribriform, and micropapillary patterns are grade 3 if > 20% of tumor; "complex pattern" fused glands or individual cells in desmoplastic stroma are also in this grade
Mucinous adenocarcinomas are not included in this scheme

Terminology.text: Malignant epithelial neoplasm with keratinization

Clinical Issues.text: Poor prognosis
Chemotherapy &/or radiation is often required
Resection is indicated for low-stage tumors in patients who can tolerate loss of lung volume
Diagnosis as squamous cell carcinoma eliminates many chemotherapy options available for adenocarcinoma or non-small cell carcinoma, not otherwise specified

Cytopathology.text: "Hard" cytoplasm resulting from production of long-chain keratins is characteristic
Orange G component of Pap stain is specific for keratinization
Keratinization may produce robin's egg blue staining pattern on Diff-Quik stain
Orangeophilic "tadpole" cells with elongated "tails" are very specific
Necrosis, keratin debris, or foreign-body giant cells may be prominent
Clumped or dark chromatin
Pyknotic nuclei common in keratinizing cells

sub_points: Limited (2-stain) immunohistochemical panel is preferred to preserve cells for molecular testing

sub_points: p16 or HPV testing may be helpful if anogenital or oropharyngeal primary is suspected

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Reactive changesDegenerating cells in setting of acute lung injury
sub_points: Degenerating cells in setting of acute lung injury

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Benign squamous cellsOral or bronchial squamous cells may show significant reactive atypia
sub_points: Oral or bronchial squamous cells may show significant reactive atypia

Definitions.text: Malignant epithelial neoplasm with keratinization

Presentation.text: Widely variable, from incidental "coin" lesion to widespread metastasis

Surgical approaches.text: Resection is indicated for low-stage tumors in patients who can tolerate loss of lung volume

Prognosis.text: May be cured by surgery (if low-stage tumor) but generally poor prognosis

Pattern.text: Individual cells, clumps, sheets, or papillary structures

Background.text: Necrosis, keratin debris, or foreign-body giant cells may be prominent

Nuclear Details.text: Clumped or dark chromatin
Pyknotic nuclei common in keratinizing cells

Cytoplasmic Details.text: "Hard" cytoplasm resulting from production of long-chain keratins is characteristic
Orange G component of Pap stain is specific for keratinization
Keratinization may produce robin's egg blue staining pattern on Diff-Quik stain
Orangeophilic "tadpole" cells with elongated "tails" are very specific

General Features.text: Typically central but may be peripheral

Histologic Features.text: Keratin pearls and intercellular bridges

Immunohistochemistry.text: Expression of p40 (most specific), p63, or CK5/6 may help to distinguish from adenocarcinomaIf no definite keratinization is seen, but immunochemistry supports squamous differentiation, diagnose as non-small cell carcinoma, favor squamous cell carcinoma
sub_points: If no definite keratinization is seen, but immunochemistry supports squamous differentiation, diagnose as non-small cell carcinoma, favor squamous cell carcinoma

Immunohistochemistry.text: PD-L1 testing often needed for evaluation of possibility of treatment with PD-1 inhibitors

Adenocarcinoma.text: Limited immunohistochemical panel (e.g., p40 and TTF-1) is preferred to allow for molecular testing

Metastatic Squamous Cell Carcinoma.text: Testing for HPV by p16, in situ hybridization, or molecular methods can be helpful to favor anogenital or head and neck origin

Reactive Changes.text: Reactive benign squamous cells or degenerating cells in acute respiratory distress syndrome

Vegetable Matter.text: Aspirated plant material may pick up orange G stain and resemble degenerated squamous cells

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Unequivocal keratinization is diagnostic
Diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma should not be made lightly because it prevents molecular testing for mutations with targeted treatment

Terminology.text: High-grade malignancy with abundant cytoplasm and neuroendocrine differentiation

Clinical Issues.text: Rapidly growing and metastasizing lung tumor
Genomic testing may be helpful to aid in treatment decisions
Poor prognosis but better than small cell carcinoma

Cytopathology.text: High cellularity
Necrotic debris
Frequent mitosis
Large nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin
Prominent nucleoli
Cytoplasm more abundant than in small cell carcinoma with less molding and crush artifact

Macroscopic.text: May be endobronchial or intraparenchymal tumor

Ancillary Tests.text: INSM1, synaptophysin, chromogranin positive
TTF-1 often positive

sub_points: Less cytoplasm and indistinct nucleoli

Definitions.text: High-grade malignancy with abundant cytoplasm and neuroendocrine differentiation

Etiology.text: Genomic analysis shows that LCNEC can be broken down into subsets that share mutation patterns with other more common lung tumors, including adenocarcinoma, small cell carcinoma, and carcinoid tumorsThese findings support contention that LCNEC category is biologically heterogenous
sub_points: These findings support contention that LCNEC category is biologically heterogenous

Presentation.text: Rapidly growing and metastasizing lung tumor

Treatment.text: Traditionally similar to small cell carcinoma but more likely to be resected if localized
Genomic analysis may be helpful to decide on chemotherapy regimens and targeted therapy for LCNECSubsets may respond better to small cell-like vs. adenocarcinoma-like therapeutic approaches
sub_points: Subsets may respond better to small cell-like vs. adenocarcinoma-like therapeutic approaches

Prognosis.text: Poor but better than prognosis for small cell carcinoma

Cellularity.text: High cellularity

Background.text: Necrotic debris

Nuclear Details.text: Large nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin
Prominent nucleoli
Frequent mitosis

Cytoplasmic Details.text: More abundant than in small cell carcinoma with less molding and crush artifact

General Features.text: Endobronchial or intraparenchymal tumor

Histologic Features.text: Abundant cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli
Neuroendocrine markers must be positive
> 10 mitotic figures per 10 HPF
Comedo-like necrosis
Organoid growth pattern resembling carcinoid

Immunohistochemistry.text: INSM1, synaptophysin, chromogranin, CD56 positive
TTF-1 often positive
Napsin A may be focally positive in adenocarcinoma-like subset

Non-Small Cell Carcinoma.text: Neuroendocrine markers (INSM1, synaptophysin, chromogranin) are absent or weak

Metastatic Neuroendocrine Carcinoma.text: Clinical history of previous tumor of utmost importance
Immunohistochemistry for TTF-1 and CDX2 may be helpful

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Neuroendocrine appearance and immunohistochemistry are key to diagnosis of LCNEC
Appears similar to small cell carcinoma but with more cytoplasm and obvious nucleoli

Clinical Issues.text: Often incidental nodules
May present with airway obstruction, paraneoplastic syndromes, or as part of syndrome of interstitial fibrosis and diffuse pulmonary neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia (DIPNECH)
Surgical resection for attempted cure often possible
Good prognosis

Cytopathology.text: Typically plasmacytoid morphology but may be spindled or oncocytic
Clumpy salt and pepper neuroendocrine chromatin
Abundant cytoplasm but may not be apparent in some cytologic preparations
Dispersed cells and aggregates that may show rosette-like, nested, trabecular, or pseudoglandular structures
Nucleoli inconspicuous but sometimes more prominent in atypical carcinoid
Mitotic activity scant in typical carcinoid but may be seen in atypical carcinoid

Ancillary Tests.text: Neuroendocrine markers key (INSM1, CD56, synaptophysin, chromogranin)
Ki-67 in cell blocks may be useful to evaluate grade
TTF-1 often positive but may be weak/focal

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: High-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas may be mimicked by carcinoid tumors due to neuroendocrine chromatin, molding, and crush artifactLook for necrosis and mitotic activity
sub_points: Look for necrosis and mitotic activity

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Bland carcinoid tumor cells may easily be dismissed as reactive bronchial cells or type II pneumocytesHigh level of suspicion needed
sub_points: High level of suspicion needed

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Metastatic neuroendocrine tumors from other sites may look identicalTTF-1 and CDX2 may be helpful
sub_points: TTF-1 and CDX2 may be helpful

Synonyms.text: Low-grade and intermediate-grade neuroendocrine tumors of lung

Presentation.text: Often incidental nodules, < 3 cm
May present with airway obstruction, paraneoplastic syndromes, or as part of syndrome of interstitial fibrosis and diffuse pulmonary neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia (DIPNECH)
Typically younger than patients with high-grade neuroendocrine tumors; not smoking related

Treatment.text: Surgery

Prognosis.text: Good prognosis

Pattern.text: Dispersed cells and aggregates that may show rosette-like, nested, trabecular, or pseudoglandular structures

Background.text: Usually clean, but necrosis may be seen in background of atypical carcinoid

Cells.text: Usually plasmacytoid morphology but may be spindled or oncocytic

Nuclear Details.text: Clumpy salt and pepper neuroendocrine chromatin
Nucleoli inconspicuous but sometimes more prominent in atypical carcinoid
May show neuroendocrine atypia with marked anisonucleosis
Mitotic activity raises possibility of atypical carcinoid or high-grade neuroendocrine carcinoma

Histologic Features.text: Distinctive organoid growth pattern
Typical carcinoid has < 2 mitoses per 2 mm² and no necrosis (tumorlet if < 0.5 cm)
Atypical carcinoid has 2-10 mitoses per 2 mm² or necrosis (usually punctate)

Immunohistochemistry.text: Neuroendocrine markers (INSM1, CD56, synaptophysin, chromogranin) and proliferation marker Ki-67
OTP is new marker that is positive in reactive neuroendocrine hyperplasia and both typical and atypical carcinoid but is negative in high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas

High-Grade Neuroendocrine Carcinomas.text: Carcinoid tumors may show molding and crush artifact resembling small cell carcinoma

Reactive Changes.text: Bland tumor cells may mimic reactive bronchial cells

Metastatic Neuroendocrine Tumors.text: TTF-1 and CDX2 immunohistochemistry may be helpful

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Atypical carcinoid cannot be reliably separated from typical carcinoid by cytology alone
Carcinoid tumors may show cytologic features concerning for high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas but lack abundant mitosis, apoptosis, and necrosis
Carcinoid tumors may be so bland as to not be recognized as neoplasm

Clinical Issues.text: Lung is one of most frequent sites of metastasis
Metastases are most often of lung, breast, or gastrointestinal origin
Multiple discrete tumors on radiology raises likelihood of metastasis
History is critically important for correct diagnosis

Cytopathology.text: Malignant cells have same morphology as originating tumor sites unless dedifferentiated
Morphologic comparison with previous specimens from other sites is of great value
Typically high cellularity
Necrosis and debris are common

Ancillary Tests.text: Immunocytochemistry panels may aid in determining origin but must be interpreted with caution
"Tissue of origin" or other gene panel molecular testing may be helpful in difficult cases

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Poorly differentiated primary vs. metastasisDistinctive morphologic and immunocytochemical features may be lacking
sub_points: Distinctive morphologic and immunocytochemical features may be lacking

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Primary vs. metastatic adenocarcinomaPrimary lung tumors may have enteric, mucinous, or signet-ring morphologies similar to metastasesLung adenocarcinoma may express enteric markers typically associated with gastrointestinal origin
sub_points: Primary lung tumors may have enteric, mucinous, or signet-ring morphologies similar to metastases
Lung adenocarcinoma may express enteric markers typically associated with gastrointestinal origin

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Primary vs. metastatic squamous cell carcinomaLung squamous cell carcinomas lack distinctive featuresHPV testing may be helpful to rule out some anogenital or head and neck primary sites
sub_points: Lung squamous cell carcinomas lack distinctive features
HPV testing may be helpful to rule out some anogenital or head and neck primary sites

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Primary vs. metastatic neuroendocrine carcinomaTTF-1 is often expressed in small cell carcinomas of extrapulmonary sites
sub_points: TTF-1 is often expressed in small cell carcinomas of extrapulmonary sites

Definitions.text: Malignant tumors transferred from distant sites, usually via hematogenous spread

Presentation.text: Awareness of presence of other prior or synchronous tumors is key

Natural History.text: Lung is one of most frequent sites of metastasis
Metastases are most often of lung, breast, or gastrointestinal origin

Radiographic Findings.text: Bilateral tumor masses make metastasis likely

Cellularity.text: Typically high cellularity

Background.text: Necrosis and debris are common in metastases

Cells.text: Malignant cells have same morphology as originating tumor sites unless dedifferentiated

Cytology-Histology Correlation.text: Morphologic comparison with previous specimens from other sites is of great value

General Features.text: Presence of multiple discrete tumors raises question of metastasis

Immunohistochemistry.text: Panels frequently aid in determining origin but are often not helpful or even confusing

Molecular Testing.text: "Tissue of origin" or other gene panel molecular tests may be last resort in difficult cases

Poorly Differentiated Primary vs. Metast.text: Distinctive morphologic and immunocytochemical features may be lacking

Primary vs. Metastatic Adenocarcinoma.text: Primary lung tumors may have enteric, mucinous, or signet-ring morphologies similar to metastases
Lung adenocarcinoma may express markers typically associated with gastrointestinal origin, such as CK20 and CDX2

Primary vs. Metastatic Squamous Cell Car.text: Lung squamous cell carcinomas lack distinctive features
HPV testing may be helpful to rule out some anogenital or head and neck primary sites

Primary vs. Metastatic Neuroendocrine Ca.text: TTF-1 is often expressed in small cell carcinomas of extrapulmonary sites

Papillary Carcinoma of Primary vs. Metas.text: Thyroid papillary carcinoma expresses TTF-1, but thyroglobulin can differentiate

Clear Cell Carcinoma of Primary vs. Meta.text: Renal cell carcinoma may express napsin A, but TTF-1 should be negative, and PAX8 should be positive

Metastatic Melanoma or Sarcoma vs. Prima.text: Melanoma and many sarcomas may rarely originate in lung

Clinical Indications.text: Can be performed at time of endoscopy and complements tissue biopsy

Benefits of cytologic sampling includeLess artifactual distortion of specimenCytologic samples are not subject to crush artifact (frequently occurs in small endoscopic biopsies)Lesions composed of fragile cells (lymphoma, small cell carcinoma) may be better preserved in cytologic sample than in tissue biopsyLess invasive procedure than tissue biopsySamples more surface area than tissue biopsyCan sample lesions in deep/challenging locations or when bleeding due to ulcer or other reasons
sub_points: Less artifactual distortion of specimenCytologic samples are not subject to crush artifact (frequently occurs in small endoscopic biopsies)Lesions composed of fragile cells (lymphoma, small cell carcinoma) may be better preserved in cytologic sample than in tissue biopsy

Clinical Indications.text: Cytology is preferred sampling method in some instances (diagnosis of candidal esophagitis, investigation of bile duct strictures, sampling of submucosal/intramural lesions)

Brushing.text: BenefitsSamples wider surface area than tissue biopsySafer for patients with high risk of bleedingMore sensitive for detection of infectious agents than biopsyBrushes can be used to sample stenotic lesions or lesions in areas that biopsy forceps cannot easily traverse (i.e., bile ducts)Samples are amenable to processing using liquid-based preparations
sub_points: Samples wider surface area than tissue biopsy
Safer for patients with high risk of bleeding
More sensitive for detection of infectious agents than biopsy

Samples are amenable to processing using liquid-based preparations

sub_points: Cannot sample predominantly infiltrative or submucosal/intramural lesions unless ulcerated

sub_points: Giardiacysts (11-12 μm, 4 nuclei, longitudinal fibrils) may also be seen on anal Pap

Infectious Agents.text: Giardia: Trophozoites are infectious
Strongyloides: Filariform larvae are infectious
Cryptosporidium:C. parvumandC. hominisoocysts are infectious
E. histolytica: Mature cysts are infectious
MAI: Infects macrophages
E. vermicularis: Egg is infective shortly after deposition

Presentation.text: Giardia: Asymptomatic or diarrhea, steatorrhea; history of drinking contaminated water
Strongyloides: Skin, GI, or pulmonary symptoms
Cryptosporidium: Acute, self-limited diarrhea
E. histolytica: Amebic colitis, dysentery, liver abscess
MAI: Immunocompromised patients, usually infects duodenum as part of disseminated process
E. vermicularis: Pruritus ani; may be asymptomatic

Treatment.text: Giardia: Metronidazole (if symptomatic)
Strongyloides: Ivermectin or albendazole (in simple infection)
Cryptosporidium: Nitazoxanide (in immunocompetent patients)
E. histolytica: Metronidazole
MAI: Macrolides, rifamycin; intrinsically resistant to many antimicrobials
E. vermicularis: Albendazole or mebendazole

Prognosis.text: In immunocompetent patients, prognosis is usually good with appropriate treatment

sub_points: Can involve endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and glandular epithelium

Terminology.text: Infection by adenovirus (AdV)Involves glandular epithelial cells
sub_points: Involves glandular epithelial cells

Clinical Issues.text: Clinical history of immunosuppression; ulceration seen on endoscopy
Symptoms vary with immune status of patient
HSV esophagitis: Odynophagia, dysphagia, chest pain, fever; multiple discrete shallow ulcers in middistal esophagus
CMV esophagitis: Odynophagia, dysphagia, multifocal erosion, or discrete ulceration
HPV: Squamous papilloma, usually asymptomatic unless very large
Adenovirus (AdV) gastritis, colitis: Epigastric pain, diarrhea, mucosal erosion/ulcer

Cytopathology.text: HSV: Margination of chromatin, multinucleation, molding of nuclei; beware mononuclear infected cells
CMV: Large infected cells with owl's eye inclusion may be exceedingly rare
AdV: Amphophilic intranuclear inclusion, may be mistaken for CMV
If liquid-based preparation is hypocellular, or if there is obscuring mucus or necrosis, consider making cytospins to better visualize cells of interest

Differential diagnostic considerationsChemotherapy, radiation, or ulcer may mimic viral changesCells with glycogenated nuclei or reactive changes may mimic koilocytesHSV1, HSV2, and varicella zoster are cytomorphologically indistinguishableIn esophageal brushing, cells with viral cytopathic effect may represent contamination from oropharyngeal lesion
sub_points: Chemotherapy, radiation, or ulcer may mimic viral changes
Cells with glycogenated nuclei or reactive changes may mimic koilocytes
HSV1, HSV2, and varicella zoster are cytomorphologically indistinguishable
In esophageal brushing, cells with viral cytopathic effect may represent contamination from oropharyngeal lesion

Ancillary Tests.text: Immunohistochemical stains can be performed on cytospins, thin-layer preparations, or cell blocks
Viral culture and PCR also available

Type III: Sporadic; not associated with autoimmune chronic atrophic gastritis, MEN1, or ZES

WHO Grading System.text: Applies to tumors examined histologically but included here for reference purposes
Updated classification allows for G1, G2, and G3 neuroendocrine neoplasms to be classified as well-differentiated NETs, separating these from NECs, which are by definition poorly differentiated

General Features.text: Normal CSF is clear and colorless
Total CSF volume: 90-150 mL (adults); 10-60 mL (children)
~ 500-600 mL/day is produced (adults)
Protein concentration: 15-45 mg/dL (1/2-1/3 of serum)
Glucose level: 50-80 mg/dL (60-80% of blood sugar)
When tumor is primary diagnostic consideration, at least 3 mL, preferably > 5 mL, should be sent to cytologic examination
CSF specimen should be processed as soon as possible in laboratory (ideally < 1 hour after LP)

Microbiologic studies crucial for definitive diagnosis of infectious meningitis
Cryptococcal antigen studies rapid and highly sensitive (~ 90%); culture also has high sensitivityUncommon capsule-deficient organisms may not be detected by antigen tests
sub_points: Uncommon capsule-deficient organisms may not be detected by antigen tests

Ancillary Tests.text: PCR testing most useful method for diagnosis of viral meningitis and is becoming primary for bacterial meningitis

Elevated opening pressure, elevated CSF protein, and low CSF glucose indicate possibility of meningitis

Clinical Issues.text: Usually brain lesion has been detected radiologically prior to cytologic examination of CSF
Adult brain tumors rarely appear in CSF; glioblastoma (GBM) is most frequent; ependymoma may also be seen
In adults, except for tumors in pineal region (to check tumor markers), lumbar puncture is usually not performed for primary brain tumors
CSF cytologic examination is important for pediatric brain tumors, especially medulloblastoma (MB), for clinical/therapeutic risk stratification

Cytopathology.text: GBM: Medium to large tumor cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and variable amount of cytoplasm
MB: Malignant small blue cells appear singly or arranged in small, cohesive groupsMitotic activity can be seen
sub_points: Mitotic activity can be seen

Pleural, Pericardial, and Peritoneal Cav.text: Lined by single layer of mesothelial cells and underlying loose fibroconnective tissue
In normal conditions, serous cavities contain minimal amount of fluid for lubrication of surfacesFluid is virtually acellular; contains rare mesothelial cells
sub_points: Fluid is virtually acellular; contains rare mesothelial cells

Pleural, Pericardial, and Peritoneal Cav.text: Variety of conditions, including neoplastic and nonneoplastic, can result in accumulation of fluid or effusionReactive mesothelial hyperplasia often associated with infections, collagen vascular disease, drug reactions, pneumothorax, chest surgery, and traumaDepending on physical, chemical, and microscopic characteristics of fluid, effusions can be subdivided into transudates and exudatesDistinction is important because most malignant effusions are exudates; therefore, cytologic evaluation of transudates is not as criticalTransudates: Result of intravascular pressure alterationAttributable to heart failure, renal failure, or cirrhosis in most instancesClear fluids with low specific gravity (< 1.015), low protein content (< 3 g/dL), and low lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level (< serum LDH)Have scant cellularityExudates: Result of mesothelium injuryMalignancy, infections, autoimmune disease, infarction, and trauma are major causesTurbid fluids with greater specific gravity (> 1.015), high protein content (> 3g/dL), and high LDH level (> serum LDH)Tend to have higher cellularity with numerous mesothelial cells, inflammatory cells, ± tumor cells
sub_points: Reactive mesothelial hyperplasia often associated with infections, collagen vascular disease, drug reactions, pneumothorax, chest surgery, and trauma
