Presence of bile pigment in dilated canaliculi helpful in distinguishing HCC from its mimics

Morphologic Subtypes.text: Steatohepatitic (most common subtype): Tumor shows histological steatohepatitis, IL-6/JAK/STAT activation; less with CTNNB1, TERT, TP53 mutations
Clear cell: > 80% tumor with clear cell morphology, some steatosis acceptable, no specific molecular alterations
Macrotrabecular massive: Macrotrabecular growth in >50% of tumor, TP53 mutations, FGF19 amplifications
Scirrhous: >50% with dense intratumoral fibrosis, TSC1/2 mutations, TGF-beta activation
Chromophobe: Light (almost clear) cytoplasm, bland tumor nuclei, some nuclear atypia, alternative lengthening of telomeres
Fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma: Large eosinophilic tumor cells, prominent nucleoli, dense intratumoral fibrosis, DNAJB1-PRKACA fusion
Neutrophil rich: Numerous intratumoral neutrophils, some with sarcomatoid areas, produces G-CSF
Lymphocyte rich: Lymphocytes outnumber tumor cells, no specific molecular alterations

Histochemistry.text: ReticulinStaining pattern: Diminished or absent in sinusoids; may outline abnormally thick trabeculae as well
sub_points: Staining pattern: Diminished or absent in sinusoids; may outline abnormally thick trabeculae as well

Histochemistry.text: DNAJB1::PRKACAfusion reported as specific recurrent abnormality in fibrolamellar subtype

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive for Hep-Par1, glypican-3, arginase-1, glutamine synthetase, and CAM5.2 (keratins 8 and 18)
AFP staining highly specific but insensitive (25%)
Polyclonal CEA and CD10 demonstrate canalicular pattern
Sinusoidal capillarization demonstrated with CD34

Cholangiocarcinoma.text: Mucicarmine (+); expresses CK7, CK19, and CA19-9
Mixed HCC/cholangiocarcinoma may show features of both

Metastatic Neuroendocrine Tumor.text: Prominent collagenous stroma; positive staining for neuroendocrine markers

Angiomyolipoma.text: Presence of adipose tissue and muscular arteries; HMB-45 and MART-1 (+), Hep-Par1(-)

Renal Cell Carcinoma.text: History of renal cell carcinoma or renal tumor, no cirrhosis

Hepatic Adenoma.text: Patient demographics differ, cirrhosis absent, trabeculae at most 2 or 3 cells thick

Regenerative Nodule in Cirrhosis.text: Cytologically benign, absence of trabecular or pseudoglandular growth pattern

Dysplastic Nodule in Cirrhosis.text: Cytologic atypia and mild architectural abnormalities
Contains portal tracts, lacks invasion of portal tracts by tumor

Edmondson and Steiner.text: Grade I (well differentiated): Small hepatocytic tumor cells arranged as trabeculae
Grade II (moderately differentiated): Larger tumor cells with abnormal nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm; pseudoglandular structures may be seen
Grade III (poorly differentiated): More frequent tumor giant cells
Grade IV (undifferentiated): Poorly differentiated tumor cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, little cytoplasm, and loss of trabecular architecture

WHO Grading System for Hepatocellular Ca.text: Grade I (well differentiated): tumor cells resemble mature hepatocytes with minimal to mild atypia, need to differentiate from benign primary hepatic lesions (confirm with loss of reticulin network, aberrant expression of immunostains like glypican-3)
Grade II (moderately differentiated): clearly malignant on H&E staining, and morphology strongly suggests hepatocellular differentiation

Grade III (poorly differentiated): clearing malignant on H&E staining, but morphology consistent with a broad spectrum of poorly differentiated carcinomas, immunostaining often necessary to confirm hepatic origin

Terminology.text: Predominantly pediatric liver tumor that mimics developing fetal or embryonal liver histologically

Aspiration Cytology: Kidney and Adrenal.name: Aspiration Cytology: Kidney and Adrenal Gland

Shape and Size.text: Surrounded by Gerota fascia and abdominal organs
Each kidney weighs ~ 150 g and measures ~ 11 x 5 x 3 cm

Cortex.text: Consists of glomeruli, proximal tubules, distal tubules, and initial portions of collecting ducts

Medulla.text: Composed of straight portions of proximal tubule, loops of Henle, and collecting ducts

Functional Unit.text: Nephron is functional unit of kidney consisting of glomerulus and associated renal tubules

Clinical Indications.text: Modern imaging technology is remarkably accurate for diagnosis of renal masses; however, renal FNA plays vital role in managing patients in certain circumstancesConfirming primary renal tumor in patients with inoperable diseaseSuspicious for metastatic tumor or infection of kidneyWhen partial nephrectomy is considered (young patients, small lesion, poor renal function, or certain types of tumor)Suspicious for urothelial carcinoma that may require ureterectomyLesions with equivocal radiology findingsDiagnosis for evacuated renal cysts
sub_points: Confirming primary renal tumor in patients with inoperable disease
Suspicious for metastatic tumor or infection of kidney
When partial nephrectomy is considered (young patients, small lesion, poor renal function, or certain types of tumor)
Suspicious for urothelial carcinoma that may require ureterectomy
Lesions with equivocal radiology findings
Diagnosis for evacuated renal cysts

Accuracy of Diagnosis.text: Accuracy of renal FNA in distinguishing benign and malignant lesions is 73-94%
Diagnostic sensitivity of 86% and specificity of 98% reported for malignant tumors
Common causes of false-negative diagnoses: Insufficient cells in cystic tumors, small tumors, or extensive necrosis
False-positive diagnoses reported in angiomyolipoma, inflammatory lesions, regenerative atypia, and infarct
Nondiagnostic rates up to 30% have been reported

Specimen Collection and Preparation.text: ProcedureRenal FNA or cores are commonly performed by radiologists under image guidance to ensure adequate sampling
sub_points: Renal FNA or cores are commonly performed by radiologists under image guidance to ensure adequate sampling

Specimen Collection and Preparation.text: Cytology preparationSimultaneous air-dried (for Diff-Quik stain) and wet-fixed (for Pap stain) preparations are recommendedDiff-Quik stain may provide valuable diagnostic features that complement those identified on Pap stainIntraprocedure adequacy check is essential to ensure adequate diagnostic materialWhen feasible, cell block should be obtained in case ancillary tests are needed
sub_points: Simultaneous air-dried (for Diff-Quik stain) and wet-fixed (for Pap stain) preparations are recommended
Diff-Quik stain may provide valuable diagnostic features that complement those identified on Pap stain
Intraprocedure adequacy check is essential to ensure adequate diagnostic material
When feasible, cell block should be obtained in case ancillary tests are needed

Complications and Contraindications.text: Subcapsular hematoma rate up to 40% has been reported
Anticoagulation medication (such as aspirin) should be discontinued 7-10 days before procedure

Pattern.text: Small flat sheets of tubular cells from various levels
Densely cellular glomeruli may be seen

Background.text: Stripped round nuclei of tubular cells
No necrosis or hemorrhage

Cell block should be attempted for possible immunohistochemistry and molecular testing

Clinical Presentation.text: Plain radiographs depict sclerotic rims in benign/slow-growing tumors (e.g., chondroblastoma, osteoid osteoma)
Lack of sclerotic rim in well-defined lytic lesion indicates faster growth (e.g., giant cell tumor)
Malignant/aggressive tumors can have moth-eaten appearance or destructive bone lesion
Periosteal reaction can be seen in benign and malignant bone tumors
CT and MR give better idea of extension, edema, and other details
Knowing age, location, and radiographic appearance can narrow differential diagnosis of primary tumors to 2-3 choices
FNA/core needle biopsy can definitively confirm diagnosis in context of consonant radiographic and clinical findings

Some variants of OSA may yield smears of low cellularity

Pattern.text: Variably sized fragments, loose clusters, and single tumor cells

Cells.text: Spindle and epithelioid tumor cells exhibiting significant pleomorphismTumor giant cells are commonly present
sub_points: Tumor giant cells are commonly present

Cells.text: Malignant epithelioid cells often have oval or plasmacytoid appearance resembling osteoblasts
Osteoid or unmineralized bone matrix production by tumor cells is characteristic feature of OSA
Osteoid is hyaline or finely fibrillar in Pap stain, metachromatic in Romanowsky stains, and faintly birefringent; osteoid can be difficult to distinguish from dense collagen
Osteoid can also be present as dense irregular clumps without associated tumor cells

Variants of conventional OSAOsteoblastic: Predominant population of malignant cells includes singly distributed plasmacytoid cells with eccentrically placed nucleus resembling osteoblastsMalignant spindle cells and pleomorphic tumor giant cells will also be presentOsteoid production by tumor cells will also be notedChondroblastic: Spindle and epithelioid tumor cells with significant pleomorphism associated with cartilaginous matrix and abundant osteoid productionFragments of hyaline cartilage with malignant cells residing in lacunar spaces are commonly encountered
sub_points: Osteoblastic: Predominant population of malignant cells includes singly distributed plasmacytoid cells with eccentrically placed nucleus resembling osteoblastsMalignant spindle cells and pleomorphic tumor giant cells will also be presentOsteoid production by tumor cells will also be noted
Malignant spindle cells and pleomorphic tumor giant cells will also be present
Osteoid production by tumor cells will also be noted

Chondroblastic: Spindle and epithelioid tumor cells with significant pleomorphism associated with cartilaginous matrix and abundant osteoid productionFragments of hyaline cartilage with malignant cells residing in lacunar spaces are commonly encountered
Fragments of hyaline cartilage with malignant cells residing in lacunar spaces are commonly encountered

Cells.text: Other types of OSATelangiectatic: Pleomorphic spindle and epithelioid cells, including tumor giant cells associated with minimal osteoid matrixAspiration smears are very bloodyFibroblastic: High-grade spindle cell tumor with varying range of atypia associated with very focal areas of osteoid productionSmall cell: Small round blue cell tumor mimicking Ewing sarcoma (EWS)/primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET) except for presence of osteoid in association with tumor cellsTumor cell demonstrates round to oval nucleus with fine chromatin, inconspicuous nucleolus, and scant cytoplasmLow-grade central OSA arising from medullary cavity: Mild to moderately atypical spindle cells with variable amounts of osteoid productionPeriosteal OSA arising on surface of bone: Features similar to chondroblastic OSA, usually of intermediate gradeParosteal OSA arising on surface of bone: Low-grade tumor with spindle cells showing minimal atypia associated with areas of cartilaginous differentiationFragments of bone ± osteoblastic rimmingHigh-grade surface OSA (high-grade bone-forming tumor arising from surface of bone) and secondary OSA arising in Paget disease, post radiation, or in course of bone diseases show features similar to conventional OSA
sub_points: Telangiectatic: Pleomorphic spindle and epithelioid cells, including tumor giant cells associated with minimal osteoid matrixAspiration smears are very bloody
Aspiration smears are very bloody
Fibroblastic: High-grade spindle cell tumor with varying range of atypia associated with very focal areas of osteoid production

Small cell: Small round blue cell tumor mimicking Ewing sarcoma (EWS)/primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET) except for presence of osteoid in association with tumor cellsTumor cell demonstrates round to oval nucleus with fine chromatin, inconspicuous nucleolus, and scant cytoplasm
Tumor cell demonstrates round to oval nucleus with fine chromatin, inconspicuous nucleolus, and scant cytoplasm
Low-grade central OSA arising from medullary cavity: Mild to moderately atypical spindle cells with variable amounts of osteoid production
Periosteal OSA arising on surface of bone: Features similar to chondroblastic OSA, usually of intermediate grade
Parosteal OSA arising on surface of bone: Low-grade tumor with spindle cells showing minimal atypia associated with areas of cartilaginous differentiationFragments of bone ± osteoblastic rimming
Fragments of bone ± osteoblastic rimming

High-grade surface OSA (high-grade bone-forming tumor arising from surface of bone) and secondary OSA arising in Paget disease, post radiation, or in course of bone diseases show features similar to conventional OSA

Nuclear Details.text: Spindle and epithelioid tumor cells in conventional OSA have round to oval and spindle-shaped nucleus with coarse chromatin, significant pleomorphism, prominent nucleolus, and increased mitotic activity
Tumor giant cells in conventional OSA can demonstrate very large bizarre multilobated nucleus or can be multinucleated with coarse nuclear chromatin and irregular nuclear membrane

Cell Block Findings.text: Osteoid is more easily appreciated in cell blocks

Immunohistochemistry.text: Immunoprofile is nonspecific and of minimal help in diagnosisCartilaginous areas in chondroblastic OSA will be positive for S100CD99 is frequently positive in small cell OSA
sub_points: Cartilaginous areas in chondroblastic OSA will be positive for S100
CD99 is frequently positive in small cell OSA

Immunohistochemistry.text: May be focally positive for keratin and EMA

Undifferentiated Pleomorphic Sarcoma.text: Cytologic findings are similar to those of OSA except for presence of osteoid in association with tumor cells in OSA and not in undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma
Usually occurs in older individuals and presents as lytic lesion in bone on imaging (unlike OSA)
Distinction between intraosseous undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma and OSA is academic oneClinical management is similar
sub_points: Clinical management is similar

Chondrosarcoma.text: In chondroblastic type of OSA and some gnathic OSAs, tumor cells are associated with abundant cartilaginous matrix mimicking chondrosarcoma
Presence of osteoid in focal areas in OSA is only distinguishing factor
Cartilaginous tumor with marked atypia, particularly in 2nd and 3rd decades of life, is highly suspicious for OSA
Presence ofIDH1orIDH2mutations supports diagnosis of chondrosarcoma

Dedifferentiated Chondrosarcoma.text: Fragments of high-grade sarcoma in dedifferentiated chondrosarcoma can show osteoid, thereby mimicking OSA
Presence of fragments is suggestive of low-grade cartilaginous neoplasm admixed with high-grade sarcoma (dedifferentiated component) noted in this type of tumor (unlike OSA)

Giant Cell Tumor.text: Reactive woven bone frequently found at periphery of giant cell tumor may mimic osteoid produced by tumor cells of OSA
Unlike OSA, osteoid in giant cell tumor is not lined by atypical tumor cells but by osteoblasts without any evidence of cytologic atypia
Location of tumor in metaphysis and imaging findings may be useful for distinction

Ewing Sarcoma/Primitive Neuroectodermal.text: Small cell variant of OSA may mimic EWSPresence of osteoid amidst tumor cells will be useful
sub_points: Presence of osteoid amidst tumor cells will be useful

Ewing Sarcoma/Primitive Neuroectodermal.text: While both small cell OSA and EWS/PNET can be positive for CD99, EWS/PNET alone will be positive for FLI-1 and show characteristic cytogenetic alteration t(11;22)(q24;q12)

Metastatic Carcinoma.text: Metastatic breast or prostate carcinoma may evoke robust osteoblastic reaction with reactive bone formation that can mimic OSAAppropriate immunohistochemical studies assist in making this distinction
sub_points: Appropriate immunohistochemical studies assist in making this distinction

Osteoblastoma.text: Fragments of bone lined by plump osteoblasts may mimic osteoblastoma-like OSA
OSA is usually larger than osteoblastoma and demonstrates significantly more atypia than benign-appearing osteoblasts in osteoblastoma
Features supporting diagnosis of OSA include infiltration of preexisting bony trabeculae on imaging, large size (> 5 cm), atypical mitotic figures, and abundant lace-like osteoid

Aneurysmal Bone Cyst.text: May mimic telangiectatic OSA based on imaging findings
Cells in cyst wall are not severely atypical (unlike in OSA)

Clinical Issues.text: Age range: 10-25 years, epiphysis-based tumor
Skeletally immature individuals, usually treated by curettage
Epiphysis-based tumor with extension into metaphysis in long bones

Imaging.text: Intramedullary, eccentric or central, well-defined tumor with sclerotic margins
Predominately radiolucent but frequently contains scattered punctate calcifications
May scallop cortex or result in its destruction

Cytopathology.text: 2 populations of cells: Mononuclear and multinucleated giant cells
Osteoclastic giant cells and smaller giant cells with nuclei similar to mononuclear cells
Mononuclear cells have nuclear grooves and reniform or coffee bean-shaped nuclei
Rare intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions

Ancillary Tests.text: Clonal abnormalities, especially involving chromosomes 5 and 8, have been identified
Recent study has shown balanced t(5;17) in chondroblastoma in chondroblasts but not osteoclast-type giant cells
Chondroblasts on IHC express nuclear H3K36M, S100 protein, and SOX9

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Giant cell tumor of boneSkeletally mature individuals, radiographically more aggressiveMutation analysis showsH3F3AandH3F3Bfound in 85% of giant cell tumors and 88% of chondroblastomasMononuclear cells in giant cell tumor of bone are H3K36M, S100 negative but express H3G34W, p63
sub_points: Skeletally mature individuals, radiographically more aggressive
Mutation analysis showsH3F3AandH3F3Bfound in 85% of giant cell tumors and 88% of chondroblastomas
Mononuclear cells in giant cell tumor of bone are H3K36M, S100 negative but express H3G34W, p63

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Chondroblastoma-like osteosarcomaRadiologically and cytologically aggressiveDoes not contain chondroid matrix or chicken-wire calcifications
sub_points: Radiologically and cytologically aggressive
Does not contain chondroid matrix or chicken-wire calcifications

Synonyms.text: Calcifying giant cell tumor, epiphyseal chondromatous giant cell tumor

Definitions.text: Benign, cartilage-producing neoplasm composed of chondroblasts

Incidence.text: Accounts for ~ 1% of primary bone tumors, < 3% of benign bone tumors, M:F = 2:1
In individuals < 18 years old, incidence is 1.18 per million
Affected individuals are typically skeletally immature (i.e., with open growth plates), between ages 10-25 years

Site.text: Arises in any bone that develops from endochondral ossification

Typically develops in epiphysis of long tubular bones (66%)Most common sites are distal and proximal femur, followed by proximal tibia and proximal humerus~ 37% limited to epiphysis~ 65% involve epiphysis and extend into metaphysisVast majority are centered in medullary cavity; intracortical and surface tumors are rare
sub_points: Most common sites are distal and proximal femur, followed by proximal tibia and proximal humerus
~ 37% limited to epiphysis
~ 65% involve epiphysis and extend into metaphysis
Vast majority are centered in medullary cavity; intracortical and surface tumors are rare

Site.text: Apophyseal origin is less frequent (25%)Usually originates in greater trochanter of femur and greater tuberosity of humerus
sub_points: Usually originates in greater trochanter of femur and greater tuberosity of humerus

Site.text: Bones of hands and feet affected in 10%
Other locations include talus, calcaneus, patella, acetabulum, iliac crest, temporal bone, and skull base
Tumors arising in metaphyseal and diaphyseal locations are rare
Almost all chondroblastomas are solitary
Chondroblastomas in adults develop in unusual locations, such as skull and facial bones

Presentation.text: Pain, tenderness, swelling, limited motion, fracture

Treatment.text: Curettage and packing with bone graft or resection
Percutaneous radiofrequency heat ablation in appropriate cases
Radiation in tumors that are in critical anatomic locations, such as skull base

Prognosis.text: Local recurrence rate: 14-18%; malignant transformation very rare; metastasis in < 1%; can recur if incompletely curetted
Higher recurrence rate in tumors arising in temporal bone and ribs
Local recurrences usually develop within first 3 years following curettageMay be detected after much longer time interval
sub_points: May be detected after much longer time interval

Prognosis.text: Pulmonary metastases from histologically benign chondroblastomas are well-recognized phenomenonMetastases are slowly progressiveMaintain histologic appearance of benign chondroblastomaRarely fatal and can be treated with resectionUsually develop > 5 years after primary diagnosis
sub_points: Metastases are slowly progressive
Maintain histologic appearance of benign chondroblastoma
Rarely fatal and can be treated with resection
Usually develop > 5 years after primary diagnosis

Radiographic Findings.text: Intramedullary, eccentric or central, well-defined tumor with sclerotic margins
Predominately radiolucent but frequently contains scattered punctate calcifications
May scallop cortex or result in its destruction
Neighboring marrow is altered by edema

Secondary aneurysmal bone cyst-like changes may cause extensive expansion of bone and periosteal reaction, mimicking more aggressive neoplasmIn chondroblastoma with extensive aneurysmal bone cyst-like changes, can sometimes be difficult to identify features of underlying primary chondroblastoma
sub_points: In chondroblastoma with extensive aneurysmal bone cyst-like changes, can sometimes be difficult to identify features of underlying primary chondroblastoma

MR Findings.text: Chondroblastoma has low or intermediate signal intensity on T1-weighted image and may be obscured by surrounding edema
Tumor has high or variable intensity on T2-weighted image
Prominent edema in marrow and soft tissue
Joint effusion is common

CT Findings.text: Chondroblastoma is oval, well demarcated, and shows internal calcifications

Bone Scan.text: Marked increased activity on bone scan

Cellularity.text: Specimens are usually cellular (can be operator dependent)
Aneurysmal bone cyst component, when present, can yield bloody smears

Pattern.text: Dispersed population of uninucleate and multinucleated giant cells; uninucleate cells predominate and can form loose aggregates or cluster

Background.text: None or bloody; may demonstrate chondroid matrix
Romanowsky (Diff-Quik) stain: Brilliant, magenta-like stroma reminiscent of pleomorphic adenomas
Pap stain: Waxy, green, and not very dramatic stroma

Cells.text: 2 populations of cells: Mononuclear and multinucleated giant cells
Giant cells can be osteoclastic type with numerous bland nuclei and inconspicuous nucleoli or can be smaller giant cells with nuclei similar to mononuclear cells
Mononuclear cells are dispersed singly, in small aggregates, or entrapped in cartilaginous stroma

Some mononuclear cells may be surrounded by characteristic chicken-wire calcification, which surrounds individual cells and results in necrosisBest seen on lightly or nondecalcified cell blocks, core needle biopsy with H&E stains, or Pap-stained smears
sub_points: Best seen on lightly or nondecalcified cell blocks, core needle biopsy with H&E stains, or Pap-stained smears

Nuclear Details.text: Mononuclear cells have characteristic nuclear grooves and reniform/bean-shaped nuclei
Rare intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions

Adequacy Criteria.text: Adequate if it explains diagnosis in correct clinical and radiologic setting

Cell Block Findings.text: Dual population of cells with mononuclear cells predominating; chicken-wire calcifications best seen on lightly decalcified H&E-stained cell block or small needle biopsy

Cytology-Histology Correlation.text: Failure to correlate with radiographs can result in misdiagnosis with possibly disastrous consequences

General Features.text: Well circumscribed, round or oval, red-gray-white, and gritty
Hemorrhagic cystic areas are common and prominent in tumors with secondary aneurysmal bone cyst-like changes

Histologic Features.text: Densely cellular with sharp margins and surrounding reactive bone
Composed of admixture of mononuclear chondroblasts and multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells
Chondroblasts grow in sheets, have eosinophilic cytoplasm delineated by well-defined cell borders
Nuclei are eccentric, reniform, or coffee bean-shaped, similar to nuclei in Langerhans cell histiocytosis
Mitotic activity and regional necrosis may be present, latter especially in calcified areas
Chondroid matrix can be pink or basophilic and sometimes resemble woven boneWell-formed hyaline cartilage uncommon
sub_points: Well-formed hyaline cartilage uncommon

Histologic Features.text: Mineralization of matrix surrounding individual cells imparts characteristic chicken-wire pattern
Osteoclast-type giant cells scattered throughout tumor, usually most numerous in areas of matrix production and hemorrhageOsteoclast-type giant cells are nonneoplastic and recruited by chondroblasts
sub_points: Osteoclast-type giant cells are nonneoplastic and recruited by chondroblasts

Histologic Features.text: Chondroblastoma abutting temporomandibular joint frequently shows intracytoplasmic hemosiderin deposition, mimicking tenosynovial giant cell tumorSome cases reported in literature likely represent tenosynovial giant cell tumor
sub_points: Some cases reported in literature likely represent tenosynovial giant cell tumor

Histologic Features.text: Necrosis in fractured tumors and in areas of prominent calcification
Vascular invasion uncommon
Concept of "malignant" chondroblastoma is controversialSome pathologists believe that most of these tumors represent either misdiagnosis or radiation-induced sarcoma
sub_points: Some pathologists believe that most of these tumors represent either misdiagnosis or radiation-induced sarcoma

Histologic Features.text: Term aggressive chondroblastoma is used for tumors that histologically have features of chondroblastoma but show destructive growth pattern radiographically
Tumor in metastatic deposits similar to that of primary and frequently surrounded by rim of reactive bone

Immunohistochemistry.text: Chondroblasts express nuclear H3K36M, S100 protein, and SOX9
Tumor cells may stain for muscle actin, keratin, and epithelial membrane antigen
Osteoclast-type giant cells stain for histiocytic markers
RANKL (stimulator of osteoclast production and activity) is expressed by tumor cellsBy this mechanism, osteoclasts are recruited into tumor and produce resorption and lysis of underlying bone
sub_points: By this mechanism, osteoclasts are recruited into tumor and produce resorption and lysis of underlying bone

Immunohistochemistry.text: Extracellular matrix stains for collagen type II

Genetic Testing.text: Clonal abnormalities, especially involving chromosomes 5 and 8, have been identified
Recent study has shown balanced t(5;17) in chondroblastoma in chondroblasts but not osteoclast-type giant cells

Giant Cell Tumor of Bone.text: Large tumor that spans epiphysis and metaphysis in skeletally mature individuals
Nuclei of mononuclear cells are morphologically identical to nuclei of osteoclast-type giant cells
Mononuclear cells in giant cell tumor of bone are H3K36M, S100 negative but express H3G34W, p63
Does not contain chondroid matrix or chicken-wire calcifications

Chondroblastoma-Like Osteosarcoma.text: Tumor cells are similar to mononuclear cells in chondroblastoma and can express S100 protein but negative for H3K36M
Tumor grows with infiltrative growth pattern
Tumor cells demonstrate greater degree of cytologic atypia
Osteosarcoma is more aggressive radiographically and clinically

Clinically Relevant Pathologic Features.text: Consider chondroblastoma if tumor located in epiphysis in skeletally immature individual

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: Cellular tumor in which mononuclear cells have eccentric cleaved nuclei, mimicking nuclei seen in Langerhans cell histiocytosisWith chicken-wire pattern of mineralization and scattered osteoclast-like giant cells
sub_points: With chicken-wire pattern of mineralization and scattered osteoclast-like giant cells

Clinical Issues.text: Conventional intramedullary chondrosarcoma (CSA) accounts for > 90% of all CSAs
Primary CSA usually develops in adults in 5th-7th decades of life
Most tumors originate in pelvis and femur
Patients usually present with pain or enlarging mass
Primary CSA; arises in normal bone
Secondary CSA; arises in association withPreexisting benign tumor: Enchondroma/enchondromatosis, osteochondroma, fibrous dysplasiaDiseased bone: Radiation, Paget disease
sub_points: Preexisting benign tumor: Enchondroma/enchondromatosis, osteochondroma, fibrous dysplasiaDiseased bone: Radiation, Paget disease
Diseased bone: Radiation, Paget disease

Cytopathology.text: Variable cellularity and atypia that increase with increasing grade of tumor
Fragments of hyaline cartilage and cartilaginous matrix in background
Graded on scale of 1-3 based on cellularity and nuclear atypia
Dedifferentiated CSA shows features of enchondroma or low-grade CSA with abrupt transition to high-grade sarcoma
Mesenchymal CSA shows small round blue cell tumor admixed with fragments of hyaline cartilage
Clear cell CSA shows chondrocytes with centrally located nucleus with minimal atypia associated with abundant clear/vacuolated cytoplasm

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Enchondroma
Fracture callus
Chondromyxoid fibroma
Chordoma
Chondroblastic osteosarcoma

Definitions.text: Malignant tumor producing cartilaginous matrix

sub_points: Arises in normal bone

Types.text: Secondary CSAArises in association withPreexisting benign tumorEnchondroma/enchondromatosis, osteochondroma, fibrous dysplasiaDiseased boneRadiation, Paget disease
sub_points: Arises in association withPreexisting benign tumorEnchondroma/enchondromatosis, osteochondroma, fibrous dysplasiaDiseased boneRadiation, Paget disease
Preexisting benign tumorEnchondroma/enchondromatosis, osteochondroma, fibrous dysplasia
Enchondroma/enchondromatosis, osteochondroma, fibrous dysplasia
Diseased boneRadiation, Paget disease
Radiation, Paget disease

Types.text: Periosteal CSA (a.k.a. juxtacortical CSA)Arises on surface of bone
sub_points: Arises on surface of bone

Types.text: Dedifferentiated CSADistinct variant of CSA containing well-differentiated cartilage tumor, either enchondroma or low-grade CSA, with abrupt transition to high-grade noncartilaginous tumor
sub_points: Distinct variant of CSA containing well-differentiated cartilage tumor, either enchondroma or low-grade CSA, with abrupt transition to high-grade noncartilaginous tumor

Types.text: Mesenchymal CSARare malignant tumor with bimorphic pattern composed of highly undifferentiated small round cells and islands of well-differentiated hyaline cartilage
sub_points: Rare malignant tumor with bimorphic pattern composed of highly undifferentiated small round cells and islands of well-differentiated hyaline cartilage

Types.text: Clear cell CSARare low-grade variant of CSA with distinct histology
sub_points: Rare low-grade variant of CSA with distinct histology

Neoplastic.text: Etiology for most CSAs is unknown
Malignant transformation of sporadic enchondromaRisk is very low (< 1%)
sub_points: Risk is very low (< 1%)

Neoplastic.text: Patients with enchondromatosis (e.g., Ollier disease or Maffucci syndrome) have increased risk of developing CSARisk of malignant transformation is 35-40%
sub_points: Risk of malignant transformation is 35-40%

Neoplastic.text: Malignant transformation of sporadic osteochondromaEstimated incidence is 0.4-2.0%
sub_points: Estimated incidence is 0.4-2.0%

Neoplastic.text: Patients with osteochondromatosis have 5-25% chance of developing CSA

Incidence.text: Primary CSA is 2nd most common primary malignant bone tumor after osteosarcoma, accounting for 20% of malignant bone tumors
Conventional intramedullary CSA accounts for > 90% of all CSAs

Age.text: Primary CSA usually develops in adults in 5th-7th decades of lifeVery rare in children
sub_points: Very rare in children

Age.text: Dedifferentiated CSA occurs usually at 50-60 years
Mesenchymal CSA can occur at any agePeak incidence: 2nd-3rd decades
sub_points: Peak incidence: 2nd-3rd decades

Age.text: Clear cell CSA age range: 12-84 years

Sex.text: Males are affected slightly more frequently than females

Site.text: Most originate in pelvis, especially in ilium, followed by proximal femur, proximal humerus, distal femur, and ribsInfrequently develop in small bones of hand and feet (1% of CSA)In long bones, usually involve metaphysis or diaphysis
sub_points: Infrequently develop in small bones of hand and feet (1% of CSA)
In long bones, usually involve metaphysis or diaphysis

Site.text: Most CSAs arising in osteochondroma originate in pelvis or femur
CSA of cranium usually involves skull base
Periosteal CSA most commonly involves distal femur
Dedifferentiated CSA usually involves pelvis, femur, or humerus
Mesenchymal CSA can involve sites, such as craniofacial bones, jawbones, ribs, ilium, and vertebra
Clear cell CSA involves epiphyseal ends of long bones

Presentation.text: Patients present with pain, enlarging mass, and (infrequently) fracture of bone
Skull base tumors frequently cause headache, diplopia, and cranial nerve palsies
In patients with osteochondroma/enchondromatosis, any change in clinical symptoms or increase in size after puberty should raise suspicion of malignant transformation

Treatment.text: Aggressive curettage for low-grade (grade 1) CSA, particularly for tumors in appendicular skeleton
High-grade CSA (grade 2 or 3) requires wide surgical resection
Radiation has been used to treat unresectable tumorsFrequently used for tumors arising in spine or skull base
sub_points: Frequently used for tumors arising in spine or skull base

Treatment.text: CSA arising in pelvis is treated with resection regardless of grade because local recurrence in this region is very difficult to treat

Prognosis.text: Histologic grade is single most important prognostic factor
Grade 1 CSAs behave in locally aggressive manner5-year survival rate: ~ 85%Deaths usually result from local recurrenceMetastases are rare
sub_points: 5-year survival rate: ~ 85%
Deaths usually result from local recurrence
Metastases are rare

Prognosis.text: Grades 2 and 3 CSAs have much worse prognosis5-year survival rate: ~ 50%
sub_points: 5-year survival rate: ~ 50%

Prognosis.text: Prognosis for secondary intramedullary CSA arising in enchondroma or enchondromatosis is same as for primary CSA and depends on grade of tumor
Prognosis of CSA arising in osteochondroma is excellent unless there is dedifferentiation
Periosteal CSA tends to recur locally
Dedifferentiated CSA has dismal prognosis90% of patients die in 2 years with distant metastasis
sub_points: 90% of patients die in 2 years with distant metastasis

Prognosis.text: Mesenchymal CSA has strong tendency for local recurrence and distant metastasis that can occur several years after initial diagnosis
Surgical excision with clear margins usually results in cure of clear cell CSAHigh rate of recurrence with curettage and marginal excision
sub_points: High rate of recurrence with curettage and marginal excision

Radiographic Findings.text: Lytic with scattered radiodensities that take form of rings, arcs caused by endochondral ossification and reactive bone formation, and irregular spiculations caused by irregular calcification of matrix
Low-grade tumors may have significant areas of mineralization and produce bone expansion, endosteal scalloping, and thickening of cortex
High-grade tumors have large radiolucent areas and cortical destruction, frequently with significant soft tissue mass

Cellularity.text: Cellularity is low in low-grade CSAs and increases with increasing grade of tumor

Pattern.text: Fragments of hyaline cartilage of variable cellularity associated with cartilaginous matrix

Background.text: Myxoid matrix resulting from chondroid matrix liquefaction with clusters and single chondrocytes
Cartilaginous matrix can be thick and dense to watery and fibrillar
Intensely metachromatic in Romanowsky stains

Cells.text: Chondrocytes located in lacunar spaces in fragments of hyaline cartilage or in cartilaginous matrix in background show varying grades of cytologic atypia depending on tumor grade
Dedifferentiated CSA shows features of low-grade conventional CSA with abrupt transition to high-grade sarcoma
Mesenchymal CSA shows biphasic pattern with undifferentiated small round cells admixed with islands of hyaline cartilage

Clear cell CSA shows features of low-grade CSA with chondrocytes exhibiting centrally located nucleus with minimal atypia, abundant clear cytoplasm, and distinct cytoplasmic membraneMultinucleated osteoclastic giant cells are commonly present
sub_points: Multinucleated osteoclastic giant cells are commonly present

Nuclear Details.text: Nuclei are round or ovalLow-grade CSA: Fine nuclear chromatin with inconspicuous nucleolusHigh-grade CSA: Coarse nuclear chromatin, often with prominent nucleolus and significant mitotic activity
sub_points: Low-grade CSA: Fine nuclear chromatin with inconspicuous nucleolus
High-grade CSA: Coarse nuclear chromatin, often with prominent nucleolus and significant mitotic activity

Nuclear Details.text: Nuclear atypia, binucleation, multinucleation, and mitotic activity increase with increasing grade of tumor
Conventional CSA is graded on scale of 1-3 based on cellularity, nuclear size, and nuclear hyperchromasiaGrading of CSA can be useful in predicting behavior
sub_points: Grading of CSA can be useful in predicting behavior

Nuclear Details.text: Grade 1: Moderate cellularity; small and dark or slightly enlarged nuclei with fine chromatin of uniform size; occasional binucleated cells are present; cytology is similar to enchondroma
Grade 2: Higher cellularity; larger hyperchromatic nuclei, often with irregular nuclear membrane with coarse nuclear chromatin; infrequent mitoses
Grade 3: Higher cellularity; significant nuclear atypia; nuclear pleomorphism and mitoses are easily detected

Cytoplasmic Details.text: Moderate to abundant cytoplasm
Vacuoles are often noted on Romanowsky stains

Genetic Testing.text: Isocitrate dehydrogenase genesIDH1andIDH2are mutated in many CSAsPrimary CSA: 38-70%Secondary CSA: 86%Periosteal CSA: 100%
sub_points: Primary CSA: 38-70%
Secondary CSA: 86%
Periosteal CSA: 100%

Genetic Testing.text: Mutation analysis can be used in difficult cases to distinguish CSA from chondroblastic osteosarcoma in small specimens

Enchondroma.text: Enchondromas yield few fragments of hyaline cartilage; chondrocytes lack atypiaCytologic features overlap with those of CSA
sub_points: Cytologic features overlap with those of CSA

Enchondroma.text: Relatively well-circumscribed tumor without infiltrative pattern by imaging studies
Permeation of bony trabeculae can be appreciated on histology specimens alone

Fracture Callus.text: Fragments of hyaline cartilage with minimal atypia in fracture callus can mimic low-grade CSACorrelation with clinical history and imaging findings will be useful for distinction
sub_points: Correlation with clinical history and imaging findings will be useful for distinction

Chondromyxoid Fibroma.text: Contains spindle and stellate tumor cells, chondrocytes, and giant cells associated with chondromyxoid matrix (unlike CSA)
Well-circumscribed, expansile, lytic tumor by imaging studies

Chordoma.text: Chondroid chordomas can be difficult to differentiate from low-grade CSA
Chondroid chordomas usually arise in skull base (unlike CSA)
Whereas both types of tumors can be positive for S100, chordomas alone stain with keratin and brachyury

Chondroblastic Osteosarcoma.text: Fragments of cartilage with high-grade nuclei associated with cartilaginous matrix in background can mimic high-grade CSAPresence of osteoid in cartilaginous tumor is useful to support diagnosis of chondroblastic osteosarcoma
sub_points: Presence of osteoid in cartilaginous tumor is useful to support diagnosis of chondroblastic osteosarcoma

Chondroblastic Osteosarcoma.text: Different imaging findings from high-grade CSA

Clinical Issues.text: Accounts for ~ 6-10% of primary malignant bone tumors
Usually arises in diaphysis or metadiaphysis of long tubular bones and flat bones of pelvis

Cytopathology.text: High cellularity with single tumor cells 1-2x size of lymphocytes
Tumor cells have round to oval nucleus with fine chromatin, inconspicuous nucleolus, and scant, often vacuolated cytoplasm
Tumor cell cytoplasm is rich in glycogenDisruption of tumor cells results in naked nuclei with vacuolated background
sub_points: Disruption of tumor cells results in naked nuclei with vacuolated background

Cytopathology.text: Common variant: Large cell Ewing sarcoma with larger tumor cells with prominent nucleolus, irregular nuclear membrane, and more cytoplasm

Ancillary Tests.text: Cells express vimentin, CD99 (90%), and FLI-1 (90%)CD99 is also expressed by many other malignant small round cell tumors, including lymphoblastic lymphoma, small cell osteosarcoma, mesenchymal chondrosarcoma, and small cell carcinomaSmall cell osteosarcoma, lymphoblastic lymphoma, and mesenchymal chondrosarcoma are negative for FLI-1, unlike Ewing sarcoma
sub_points: CD99 is also expressed by many other malignant small round cell tumors, including lymphoblastic lymphoma, small cell osteosarcoma, mesenchymal chondrosarcoma, and small cell carcinoma
Small cell osteosarcoma, lymphoblastic lymphoma, and mesenchymal chondrosarcoma are negative for FLI-1, unlike Ewing sarcoma

Ancillary Tests.text: Molecular testing: ~ 85% harbor t(11;22)(q24;q12)

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Malignant lymphoma
Neuroblastoma
Small cell osteosarcoma
Mesenchymal chondrosarcoma

Definitions.text: Round cell sarcoma showing variable degree of neuroectodermal differentiation

Incidence.text: Accounts for 6-10% of primary malignant bone tumors
Follows osteosarcoma and chondrosarcoma in frequency in adults
Follows osteosarcoma in frequency in children and adolescents

Age.text: Most patients are 10-15 years old~ 80% of patients are < 20 years old
sub_points: ~ 80% of patients are < 20 years old

Ethnicity.text: Striking predilection for White patients (3 per 1 million)
Africans, Asians, and Native American patients are rarely affected (0.2 per 1 million)

Site.text: Can arise in any portion of skeleton
Usually develops in diaphysis or metadiaphysis of long tubular bones and flat pelvic bones
~ 22% arise in femur, followed by ilium, tibia, humerus, fibula, and ribs
Tumor that originates in chest wall is called Askin tumor

Presentation.text: Painful enlarging mass; affected site is frequently tender, warm, and swollen
Some patients present with systemic findings that mimic infection with fever, elevated sedimentation rate, anemia, and leukocytosis
Pathologic fracture is uncommon presentation

Treatment.text: Usually treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery
Radiotherapy is reserved for tumors located in surgically inaccessible sites, for surgical beds in which tumors have been excised with inadequate margins, and for palliation

Prognosis.text: Effective chemotherapy has improved 5-year survival rate from 5-15% to 75%At least 50% are long-term curesImportant factors influencing prognosis are stage of disease at time of diagnosis and site of tumorOther prognostic factors: Type of translocation, percentage of chemotherapy-related tumor necrosis, presence of chimeric transcripts in peripheral blood or bone marrow cells after treatment, and local recurrence of tumor
sub_points: At least 50% are long-term cures
Important factors influencing prognosis are stage of disease at time of diagnosis and site of tumor

Other prognostic factors: Type of translocation, percentage of chemotherapy-related tumor necrosis, presence of chimeric transcripts in peripheral blood or bone marrow cells after treatment, and local recurrence of tumor

Radiographic Findings.text: Intraosseous destructive and lytic tumor with poorly defined margins
Permeation of cortex usually results in concentric soft tissue mass that can be very largeExtraosseous tumor frequently erodes outer cortex, producing "saucerization" of bone
sub_points: Extraosseous tumor frequently erodes outer cortex, producing "saucerization" of bone

Radiographic Findings.text: Displaced periosteum deposit layers of reactive bone in onion skin-like or sunburst-like fashion

MR Findings.text: Helpful in mapping intra- and extraosseous extent of tumor and relationship of mass to important anatomic structures
Low signal intensity on T1-weighted images; high signal intensity on T2-weighted imagesMay be useful in assessing post-chemotherapy tumor viability
sub_points: May be useful in assessing post-chemotherapy tumor viability

CT Findings.text: Large, destructive intraosseous mass with extension into soft tissues

Bone Scan.text: Tumor has avid uptake of radionuclides

Cellularity.text: High cellularity

Pattern.text: Tumor cells are predominantly singly distributed with few small sheets and loose clusters
Homer Wright rosettes with central neuropil suggesting neural differentiation can be seen with primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET) but not with EWS

Background.text: Vacuolated tigroid background due to disruption of tumor cells with high glycogen content in cytoplasm
Necrosis is variable

Cells.text: Tumor cells are 1-2x size of lymphocytes
Dimorphic or 2-cell population of light and dark cells is often noted, particularly on Romanowsky stains
Light and dark cells reflect viable and dying tumor cells

Variants of EWSLarge cell variant: Large tumor cells with prominent nucleolus, irregular nuclear membrane, and more cytoplasmAdamantinoma-like variant: Clusters of moderately pleomorphic tumor cells with peripheral palisading and desmoplasiaSpindle cell sarcoma-like variant: Spindle tumor cells mimicking other spindle cell sarcomasSclerosing variant: Tumor cells associated with hyalinized matrix
sub_points: Large cell variant: Large tumor cells with prominent nucleolus, irregular nuclear membrane, and more cytoplasm
Adamantinoma-like variant: Clusters of moderately pleomorphic tumor cells with peripheral palisading and desmoplasia
Spindle cell sarcoma-like variant: Spindle tumor cells mimicking other spindle cell sarcomas
Sclerosing variant: Tumor cells associated with hyalinized matrix

Nuclear Details.text: Viable (light) cells show round to oval nuclei, fine nuclear chromatin, and inconspicuous nucleolus
1-3 small nucleoli can be seen in tumor cells
Dying (dark) cells resemble lymphocytes with dense nuclear chromatin and thin rim of scant cytoplasm
Binucleation and multinucleation are usually absent
Mitotic activity is variable

Cytoplasmic Details.text: Cytoplasm can be vacuolated or clear due to glycogen content
Cytoplasmic vacuoles can be coarse and punched-out in Romanowsky stain or delicately vacuolated and clear in Pap stain

Variants.text: Large cell EWS: Larger tumor cells with prominent nucleolus, irregular nuclear membrane, and more cytoplasm
Adamantinoma-like variant: Clusters of moderately pleomorphic cells with peripheral palisading and desmoplasia
Spindle cell sarcoma-like variant: Spindle tumor cells resembling synovial sarcoma
Sclerosing variant: Tumor cells associated with hyalinized matrix

Immunohistochemistry.text: Cells express vimentin, CD99 (90%), and FLI-1 (90%)Other tumors, such as small cell osteosarcoma, mesenchymal chondrosarcoma, and lymphoblastic lymphoma, can also be positive for CD99 but are negative for FLI-1Tumors with neuroectodermal differentiation express 1 or more neural markers, including NSE, CD57, and S100
sub_points: Other tumors, such as small cell osteosarcoma, mesenchymal chondrosarcoma, and lymphoblastic lymphoma, can also be positive for CD99 but are negative for FLI-1
Tumors with neuroectodermal differentiation express 1 or more neural markers, including NSE, CD57, and S100

Immunohistochemistry.text: Neurofilament and keratin positivity can be seen in ~ 20% of cases

Electron Microscopy.text: Tumor cells are primitive in appearance with few organelles, such asMitochondria, poorly developed Golgi complexes, free ribosomes, and inconspicuous rough endoplasmic reticulum associated with abundant cytoplasmic glycogen
sub_points: Mitochondria, poorly developed Golgi complexes, free ribosomes, and inconspicuous rough endoplasmic reticulum associated with abundant cytoplasmic glycogen

Electron Microscopy.text: Neural differentiation suggested by interdigitating cytoplasmic cell processes connected by primitive junctions, scattered microtubules, and neurosecretory granules
Definite tonofibrils and well-developed basal lamina can be identified in some keratin-positive tumors

Molecular Pathology.text: SomeEWS-negative tumors have been shown to harborFUS::ERGfusion t(16;21)Tumors negative forFUS/ERGmay showCIC::DUX4fusion
sub_points: Tumors negative forFUS/ERGmay showCIC::DUX4fusion

Malignant Lymphoma.text: Cells in large cell lymphoma are frequently larger and exhibit more cytoplasm; their nuclei are often irregular, cleaved, and hyperlobated, unlike EWS
Lymphoblastic lymphoma is composed of uniform round cells that can be similar to EWSPresence of lymphoglandular bodies in background of smears will be useful
sub_points: Presence of lymphoglandular bodies in background of smears will be useful

Malignant Lymphoma.text: Lymphomas can also express CD99 but are FLI-1 negative and TdT positive, unlike EWS
Ultrastructurally, tumor cells of lymphoma have marginated chromatin, lack intercellular junctions, and do not contain glycogen
Chromosomal translocations associated with malignant lymphoma do not include those identified in EWS

Neuroblastoma.text: Cytologic features of metastatic undifferentiated neuroblastoma are similar to those of EWSPresence of neuropils and ganglion cells in neuroblastoma may be useful for distinction
sub_points: Presence of neuropils and ganglion cells in neuroblastoma may be useful for distinction

Neuroblastoma.text: Negative for CD99 and FLI-1, unlike EWS
ShowsMYCNamplification and loss of 1p, whereas EWS::PNET shows characteristic t(11;22)(q24;q12)

Small Cell Osteosarcoma.text: Tumor cells of small cell osteosarcoma and EWS may be similarPresence of neoplastic osteoid in small cell osteosarcoma may be useful for distinctionEWS may contain reactive woven bone that can cause confusion with osteosarcomaOsteoblastic rimming of woven bone may be usefulAncillary immunostain for FLI-1 and cytogenetic analysis are useful
sub_points: Presence of neoplastic osteoid in small cell osteosarcoma may be useful for distinction
EWS may contain reactive woven bone that can cause confusion with osteosarcomaOsteoblastic rimming of woven bone may be useful
Osteoblastic rimming of woven bone may be useful
Ancillary immunostain for FLI-1 and cytogenetic analysis are useful

Mesenchymal Chondrosarcoma.text: Tumor cells may mimic those of EWS
Areas of chondroid differentiation admixed with tumor cellsThis characteristic is useful in differentiating from EWS
sub_points: This characteristic is useful in differentiating from EWS

Mesenchymal Chondrosarcoma.text: Can be positive for CD99 but negative for FLI-1 and does not show characteristic cytogenetic alteration of EWS

Clinical Issues.text: Accounts for ~ 5% of primary malignant bone tumors
Usually diagnosed during 4th-8th decades; M > F
Only 5% of tumors develop in patients < 20 years
Virtually restricted to axial skeleton
Most (~ 50%) arise in sacrum, 35% in skull base
Mobile spine is site of origin in 15%
Tumors in children usually arise in skull base

Imaging.text: Destructive &/or lytic with soft tissue extension ± calcifications
In sacrum, soft tissue component is anterior

Cytopathology.text: Cellular specimens with magenta background stroma on Romanowsky stains
Combination of large vacuolated cells and smaller cells with granular cytoplasm
Large physaliferous/spider cells with multiple vacuoles and cytoplasmic processes that stretch from nucleus to periphery of cell separated by vacuoles may be seen
Correlation of radiologic, clinical, and cytologic findings is key to diagnosis

Ancillary Tests.text: Keratin, S100, T-Brachyury (nuclear) positive

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Metastatic adenocarcinomaS100 and T-Brachyury negative in adenocarcinomas
sub_points: S100 and T-Brachyury negative in adenocarcinomas

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: ChondrosarcomaNegative for keratin, EMA, and T-Brachyury
sub_points: Negative for keratin, EMA, and T-Brachyury

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Metastatic renal cell carcinomaT-Brachyury negative, PAX8 positive
sub_points: T-Brachyury negative, PAX8 positive

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Benign notochordal cell tumorConfined to bone and lack extracellular myxoid matrix histologically
sub_points: Confined to bone and lack extracellular myxoid matrix histologically

Definitions.text: Primary malignant tumor of bone with phenotype that recapitulates notochord and usually arises within bones of axial skeleton
Chondroid chordoma: Tumor with areas of conventional chordoma and regions resembling low-grade, hyaline-type chondrosarcoma
Dedifferentiated chordoma contains chordoma juxtaposed to high-grade sarcoma

Neoplastic.text: Benign notochordal cell tumor (BNCT) thought to be precursor lesion to chordoma
Variety of genetic abnormalities can be identified in sporadic and familial tumorsFamilial tumors have been associated with upregulation of T-Brachyury, nuclear transcription factor
sub_points: Familial tumors have been associated with upregulation of T-Brachyury, nuclear transcription factor

Neoplastic.text: Appears to be increased incidence of chordoma in patients with tuberous sclerosis

Incidence.text: ~ 5% of primary malignant bone tumors

Age.text: Usually diagnosed during 4th-8th decades
Only 5% of tumors develop in patients < 20 yearsTumors in children usually arise in skull base
sub_points: Tumors in children usually arise in skull base

Site.text: Virtually restricted to axial skeletonRare cases reported to arise outside axial skeletonSoft tissue chordomas recently described
sub_points: Rare cases reported to arise outside axial skeleton
Soft tissue chordomas recently described

Site.text: Most (~ 50%) arise in sacrum, 35% in skull base
Mobile spine is site of origin in 15%
Chondroid chordoma usually arises in skull baseMuch less frequently in mobile spine and sacrococcygeal region
sub_points: Much less frequently in mobile spine and sacrococcygeal region

Presentation.text: Depends on site of originSkull base: Diplopia, headaches, cranial nerve palsiesMobile spine: Pain, neurologic symptomsSacrum: Pain, constipation, incontinence, bladder dysfunction, erectile dysfunction
sub_points: Skull base: Diplopia, headaches, cranial nerve palsies
Mobile spine: Pain, neurologic symptoms
Sacrum: Pain, constipation, incontinence, bladder dysfunction, erectile dysfunction

Treatment.text: Standard of care is combination of surgery and radiationNo effective chemotherapy currently available
sub_points: No effective chemotherapy currently available

Prognosis.text: Affected by tumor subtype, location, size, and resectability
Dedifferentiated chordomas that have high-grade sarcomatous areas and poorly differentiated chordomas, which are SMARCB1 (INI1) negative, have worst prognosis

Sacral chordomas have best prognosis and longest overall survival, as they can be resected with negative marginsLocal recurrences for sacrococcygeal tumors are common after incomplete excision5- and 10-year survival rates range from 60-95% and 40-60%, respectively
sub_points: Local recurrences for sacrococcygeal tumors are common after incomplete excision
5- and 10-year survival rates range from 60-95% and 40-60%, respectively

Prognosis.text: In mobile spine, 5-year survival rate is ~ 55% with local recurrence rate ranging from 62-75%Primarily due to difficulty in achieving complete resection
sub_points: Primarily due to difficulty in achieving complete resection

Prognosis.text: In skull base, large tumors, female sex, and age > 40 years associated with poorer outcomeIn series in which patients were treated with surgery and radiation, 46% developed local progression with median follow-up of 69 monthsOthers have reported 5-year local control rate of 59%
sub_points: In series in which patients were treated with surgery and radiation, 46% developed local progression with median follow-up of 69 monthsOthers have reported 5-year local control rate of 59%
Others have reported 5-year local control rate of 59%

Prognosis.text: No difference in overall survival for patients with chondroid chordomas
Dedifferentiated chordoma has worst prognosis of all chordomasUsually rapidly fatal with systemic spread occurring in ~ 90% of cases
sub_points: Usually rapidly fatal with systemic spread occurring in ~ 90% of cases

Prognosis.text: Rate of metastatic spread varies widelyRanges from < 5-43% (highest for dedifferentiated chordoma)
sub_points: Ranges from < 5-43% (highest for dedifferentiated chordoma)

Prognosis.text: Common sites of dissemination include lung, skin, and bone

Radiographic Findings.text: Destructive &/or lytic with soft tissue extension ± calcifications
In sacrum, soft tissue component is characteristically anteriorMay displace rectum and extend along sacral nerve roots into sciatic notch
sub_points: May displace rectum and extend along sacral nerve roots into sciatic notch

Radiographic Findings.text: Sacral tumors are notoriously difficult to see on conventional radiographs

MR Findings.text: Extremely bright on T2-weighted images
May show lobulated pattern
Foci of calcification are frequently seen
Soft tissue extent better seen

CT Findings.text: High water content and radiolucent appearance

Cellularity.text: Usually cellular but can be operator dependent

Pattern.text: Dispersed large cells or small groups of large vacuolated cells

Background.text: Abundant mucoid background that stains magenta on Romanowsky stains (Diff-Quik) at time of adequacy evaluation; rarely fibrillary

Cells.text: 2 populationsLarge cells with signet-ring appearance due to cytoplasmic vacuolesOr large physaliferous/spider cells with multiple vacuoles and cytoplasmic processes that stretch from nucleus to periphery of cell separated by vacuolesSmaller cells with granular cytoplasm; nuclei are small and bland with dispersed to vesicular chromatin and occasional nucleoli or chromocenters
sub_points: Large cells with signet-ring appearance due to cytoplasmic vacuolesOr large physaliferous/spider cells with multiple vacuoles and cytoplasmic processes that stretch from nucleus to periphery of cell separated by vacuoles
Or large physaliferous/spider cells with multiple vacuoles and cytoplasmic processes that stretch from nucleus to periphery of cell separated by vacuoles
Smaller cells with granular cytoplasm; nuclei are small and bland with dispersed to vesicular chromatin and occasional nucleoli or chromocenters

General Features.text: Soft, tan-gray, gelatinous, and lobulated
Well delineated from surrounding tissues
Dedifferentiated component is solid and fish flesh-like in appearance

Size.text: Tumors in skull base are smallest and usually 2-5 cm in diameter
Sacral tumors can be very large, usually > 10 cm

Histologic Features.text: Histologically, chordoma is classified into conventional chordoma, chondroid chordoma, and dedifferentiated chordoma

Conventional chordoma has lobular growth pattern, infiltrates marrow space, encases preexisting bony trabeculae, and usually transgresses cortex, forming well-demarcated soft tissue massComposed of large epithelioid cells arranged in cohesive nests and cords1 tumor cell may wrap around or "hug" anotherNuclei are of moderate size, darkly staining, and may contain small nucleoli or pseudoinclusionsAbundant eosinophilic cytoplasmMay contain multiple round, clear vacuoles that may harbor wisps of mucinous materialIntracytoplasmic vacuoles impart bubbly appearance to cytoplasm, and cells containing them are known as physaliphorous cellsPhysaliphorous cells are not pathognomonic of chordoma, as other types of tumors may have similar-appearing cells, and some chordomas may lack themIn some tumors, physaliphorous cells have large single cytoplasmic vacuole that causes them to mimic adipocytesPleomorphism and spindling of tumor cells may be present in conventional chordomaMitotic activity is usually limited in conventional chordomaFoci of necrosis are common, especially in larger tumorsExtracellular stroma is myxoid, frothy, basophilic

1 tumor cell may wrap around or "hug" another

Intracytoplasmic vacuoles impart bubbly appearance to cytoplasm, and cells containing them are known as physaliphorous cellsPhysaliphorous cells are not pathognomonic of chordoma, as other types of tumors may have similar-appearing cells, and some chordomas may lack themIn some tumors, physaliphorous cells have large single cytoplasmic vacuole that causes them to mimic adipocytes

Histologic Features.text: Chondroid chordoma contains areas of conventional chordoma as well as regions resembling low-grade, hyaline-type chondrosarcomaChondroid regions merge with or abruptly abut surrounding conventional componentChondroid areas composed of neoplastic cells distributed individually in lacunar-like spacesNeoplastic cells are surrounded by solid-appearing hyalinized matrix similar in appearance to hyaline cartilageQuantity of chondroid component in any individual tumor is variableIn some tumors, chondroid areas are so abundant that it may be difficult to distinguish tumor from chondrosarcoma
sub_points: Chondroid regions merge with or abruptly abut surrounding conventional component

Chondroid areas composed of neoplastic cells distributed individually in lacunar-like spacesNeoplastic cells are surrounded by solid-appearing hyalinized matrix similar in appearance to hyaline cartilage

In some tumors, chondroid areas are so abundant that it may be difficult to distinguish tumor from chondrosarcoma

Histologic Features.text: Dedifferentiated chordoma is composed of high-grade sarcoma juxtaposed with conventional chordomaSarcoma is usually high-grade, undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcomaDedifferentiation results from ongoing cumulative mutations in conventional chordoma cells
sub_points: Sarcoma is usually high-grade, undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma
Dedifferentiation results from ongoing cumulative mutations in conventional chordoma cells

Histologic Features.text: In some tumors, areas of BNCT may be seen adjacent to chordoma, suggesting malignant transformation

Ultrastructural Features.text: Neoplastic cells in conventional chordoma have villous-like surface projections, abundant cytoplasmic glycogen, and mitochondria-rough endoplasmic reticulum complexes
Contain cytoplasmic processes that wrap around adjacent cellCells have well-developed desmosomes, intracytoplasmic lumina, and tonofilaments
sub_points: Cells have well-developed desmosomes, intracytoplasmic lumina, and tonofilaments

Ultrastructural Features.text: Tumor cells in chondroid areas exhibit same epithelial characteristics as those in conventional foci

Immunohistochemistry.text: Conventional chordoma typically expresses epithelial markers, keratin and EMAIncludes keratins 8 and 19 and EMA
sub_points: Includes keratins 8 and 19 and EMA

Immunohistochemistry.text: Vast majority stain for nuclear transcription factor T-Brachyury and for S100
Variable numbers may also stain with antibodies to carcinoembryonic antigen and glial fibrillary acidic protein

Metastatic Adenocarcinoma.text: Mucinous adenocarcinoma can mimic chordoma on small biopsy sample
S100 and T-Brachyury negative in adenocarcinomas

Chondrosarcoma, Especially Myxoid Type.text: Negative for keratin, EMA, and T-Brachyury

Benign Notochordal Cell Tumor.text: BNCT contains cells with abundant clear cytoplasm (adipocyte-like) or eosinophilic cytoplasm
Has same immunohistochemical profile as chordoma
Unlike chordoma, BNCTs are usually confined to bone and lack extracellular myxoid matrix histologically
Radiographically, chordoma is lytic, whereas BNCT is sclerotic and does not show contrast enhancement

Clinical Issues.text: Represents ~ 6% of primary bone tumors
Vast majority arise in epiphyseal-metaphyseal region of long tubular bones
Pain and swelling
Epiphyseal metaphyseal lytic lesion in distal long bone extending to subchondral area in adult patient is characteristic

Cytopathology.text: Cellular aspirates that may be bloody
Dispersed or checkerboard pattern of giant cells and uninucleate stromal cells, which may be spindle-shaped or round
Giant cells may have up to 100 nuclei
Nuclei of stromal and giant cells are similarly characterized by vesicular chromatin and nucleoli
Uninucleate stromal cells can be mitotically active

Giant cells have abundant cytoplasm; uninucleate cells have variable amounts of trailing cytoplasmBoth can contain vacuoles and metachromatic granules on Diff-Quik stainFollowing receptor activator of nuclear factor-κ Β (RANK) ligand inhibitor therapy (denosumab), giant cells disappear, mononuclear tumor cells decrease, and bone formation increases
sub_points: Both can contain vacuoles and metachromatic granules on Diff-Quik stain
Following receptor activator of nuclear factor-κ Β (RANK) ligand inhibitor therapy (denosumab), giant cells disappear, mononuclear tumor cells decrease, and bone formation increases

Ancillary Tests.text: Giant cells have immunoprofile similar to macrophages
Osteoclast-type giant cells stain for RANK
Molecular testing for H3F3A [in > 90% of giant cell tumors (GCTs)] and H3F3B helps differentiate between GCT and chondroblastoma
IHC for H3G34W sensitive and specific for GCT; small percentage negative due to alternate mutations

Top Differential Diagnoses.text: Nonossifying fibroma, chondroblastoma, giant cell reparative granuloma, aneurysmal bone cyst, giant cell-rich osteosarcoma

Definitions.text: Benign, but locally aggressive, neoplasm composed of cytologically banal, oval or polyhedral mononuclear cells admixed with numerous evenly distributed, osteoclast-like giant cells

Neoplastic.text: Mononuclear cells are neoplastic cells of possible osteoblast phenotype that induce formation of osteoclast-type giant cells by expressing receptor activator of nuclear factor-κ Β (RANK) ligand

Incidence.text: Represents ~ 6% of primary bone tumorsRepresents ~ 20% of benign bone tumors
sub_points: Represents ~ 20% of benign bone tumors

Age.text: Skeletally mature individuals during 3rd-5th decades of life
Rarely occurs in children

Sex.text: Females are affected slightly more frequently than males

Site.text: Vast majority arise in epiphyseal-metaphyseal region of long tubular bones, especially around knees and distal radius, 5-15 cm
Tumors in patients with open growth plates are often centered in metaphysis and abut epiphyseal plateRarely arise in diaphysis
sub_points: Rarely arise in diaphysis

Site.text: In almost 1/2 of cases, GCT develops around knee with predilection for distal femur followed by proximal tibia and distal radius

Uncommon sites include vertebral bodies, short tubular bones of hands and feet, craniofacial bones, and patellaMany GCTs of bone that arise in craniofacial skeleton occur in setting of Paget disease of bone
sub_points: Many GCTs of bone that arise in craniofacial skeleton occur in setting of Paget disease of bone

Site.text: Usually solitary1% of cases are multifocal, and these often affect bones of hands and feet
sub_points: 1% of cases are multifocal, and these often affect bones of hands and feet

Presentation.text: Pain, swelling, pathologic fracture in minority of cases

Surgical approaches.text: Usually treated by thorough curettage
En bloc resection for large tumors with little residual structural bone

Drugs.text: Preliminary studies with RANK ligand inhibitors, such as denosumab, seem to be effective and may possibly supplement radiation treatment and surgery in difficult casesTumor locally recurs if drug therapy is discontinued
sub_points: Tumor locally recurs if drug therapy is discontinued

Radiation.text: Can be used in surgically inaccessible tumors, when surgical treatment would result in significant morbidity, or when medical problems preclude surgical intervention

Prognosis.text: Local recurrence rate is ~ 25% for patients treated with curettage, usually within 3 years

Although giant cell tumor (GCT) of bone is classified as benign neoplasm, 1-2% eventually metastasize, primarily to lungsMetastatic deposits frequently cured by resectionMetastatic disease can also be treated with RANK ligand inhibitors, such as denosumabMetastases occur more frequently in patients with pathologic fracture or following multiple curettages for recurrent disease
sub_points: Metastatic deposits frequently cured by resection
Metastatic disease can also be treated with RANK ligand inhibitors, such as denosumab
Metastases occur more frequently in patients with pathologic fracture or following multiple curettages for recurrent disease

sub_points: May occur de novo, develop in locally recurrent tumor, or happen following radiation therapy

Radiographic Findings.text: Large, lytic, intramedullary, and frequently eccentric

sub_points: Results in thin periosteal shell of reactive bone, which may be incomplete

Background.text: May be bloody

sub_points: Nuclei of mononuclear cells identical to those of osteoclast-type giant cells

Pathologic Interpretation Pearls.text: If needle biopsy appears as fibrous histiocytoma, think possible GCT

Terminology.text: Primary lymphoma originating in bone ± soft tissue extension

Clinical Issues.text: Usually adults~ 50% are > 40 years
sub_points: ~ 50% are > 40 years

Clinical Issues.text: Femur is most common location, followed by pelvis, vertebrae, and humerus
~ 10-40% of cases of lymphoma are multifocal/polyostotic

Cellularity.text: Variable

Pattern.text: Fascicular fragments, naked nuclei, ± intact single cells

Background.text: ± myxoid stroma, ± necrosisInflammatory infiltration, including small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and histiocytes often as aggregates of foam cells
sub_points: Inflammatory infiltration, including small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and histiocytes often as aggregates of foam cells

Cells.text: Spindle cells with indistinct borders, ± rounded/polygonal cells, ↑ pleomorphism with tumor grade

Nuclear Details.text: Cigar-shaped, elongated nuclei with blunt ends, ± indentations, ± cytoplasmic nuclear inclusions, ± palisading
Atypia and mitoses ↑ with tumor grade
Granular chromatin, ± striated appearance, usually inconspicuous nucleoli

Cytoplasmic Details.text: Abundant, finely granular/fibrillar, ± perinuclear vacuoles

Immunohistochemistry.text: Positive: Desmin, SMA, MSA, calponin, caldesmon
Variably positive: Keratin, EMA, CD99
Usually negative: S100, β-catenin (nuclear), CD34, C-kit, DOG1, TLE1, ALK, MyoD1, myogenin, p63, cyclin-D1

Genetic Testing.text: Complex variable karyotypes

No characteristic translocation, mutation, or fusion product knownInflammatory leiomyosarcoma can show differentially expressed genes involved in muscle development and function, includingITGA7,MYF5,MYF6,MYOD1,MYOG,PAX7EBV-associated smooth muscle tumors show diffuse nuclear positivity for EBV-encoded ribonucleic acid by in situ hybridization

Malignant Entities.text: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor, rhabdomyosarcoma, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, sarcomatoid carcinoma, melanoma, fibrosarcoma, myofibrosarcoma, synovial sarcoma, pleomorphic sarcomas, mesothelioma

Definitions.text: Benign tumor of blood vessels

Presentation.text: Common soft tissue tumor at any age
Most often in skin/subcutaneous tissue but also in liver and other sites
Single or multiple
Most are clinically obvious and not aspiratedSome deep sites receive FNA to exclude malignancy if diagnosis is not obvious
sub_points: Some deep sites receive FNA to exclude malignancy if diagnosis is not obvious

Cellularity.text: Scanty to acellular; often nondiagnostic

Pattern.text: Rare tissue fragments or isolated spindle cells; rarely polygonal cells ± tangles/swirls of cells

Background.text: Very bloody ± fibrous stromal fragments

Cells.text: Bland, uniform spindle cells; rarely polygonal cells ± minimal pleomorphism

Nuclear Details.text: Elongate/oval nuclei ± longitudinal groove/fold in nuclear membrane, fine chromatin, indistinct nucleoli

Cytoplasmic Details.text: Moderate amount, varies from pale to dense

Cell Block Findings.text: Can be diagnostic if obtained tissue shows vascular channels lined by benign endothelium

Immunohistochemistry.text: Endothelial markers: Factor VIII, CD31, CD34, FLI-1, ERG, ± D2-40 (podoplanin) ±Ulex europaeus

Other Reactive and Neoplastic Soft Tissu.name: Other Reactive and Neoplastic Soft Tissue Entities

General Features.text: Benign, self-limited but rapidly growing myofibroblastic mass that produces cellular proliferation and is mitotically active in its early stages
Head and neck areas, upper trunk, and upper extremities; superficial location; patients usually in 3rd-4th decades
Histologically, loose storiform feathery pattern with tissue culture-like appearance and loose myxoid stroma ± cystic spaces and dense keloid-like collagen
Osteoclast-like giant cells, histiocytes, lymphocytes, and extravasated erythrocytes can be seen
3 forms correlating with duration of lesion: Myxoid [earliest (within days)], cellular, and fibrous
Variants include nodular myositis, intravascular fasciitis, cranial fasciitis, and proliferative funiculitis

Molecular: Majority (> 90%) overexpressUSP6gene rearrangement (located on 17p13) with most common partner (in 60%) beingMYH9,(located on 22q12.3-q13); FISH testing available and helpful on cytology specimens and in difficult cases
IHC: Cytokeratin, CD34, muscle markers, and nuclear β-catenin negative

Cytology.text: Aspirates can be cellular depending on phase of lesion
Background can be myxoid with scattered lymphocytes, macrophages, and (rarely) osteoclastic giant cells
Mitosis may be seen but is not atypical
Loosely arranged plump to stellate spindle cells
May be misdiagnosed as sarcomaSuperficial location and age are important
sub_points: Superficial location and age are important

General Features.text: Tumefactive intramuscular or subcutaneous proliferation featuring ganglion-like fibroblasts in background of myofibroblasts and fibroblasts, similar to nodular fasciitis
Presents in middle age and older adults with painless, poorly circumscribed mass, growing rapidly along connective tissue septa
Histologically characterized by plump stellate to spindle-shaped myofibroblasts and fibroblasts with background lymphocytes and extravasated erythrocytes
Large ganglion-like cells with macronucleoli and abundant cytoplasm
Brisk mitotic activity may result in misinterpretation as sarcoma;USP6gene rearrangement demonstrated by FISH
Diploid on flow cytometry; vimentin (+), actin (-), desmin (-), myogenin (-)
Patients are usually middle-aged or older adults

Cytology.text: Variably cellular aspirates with large ganglion-like cells with prominent nucleoli
Background stellate cells, myxoid stroma, lymphocytes, and erythrocytes
Degenerating skeletal muscle fibers with striations may be seen
Differential diagnosis: Pleomorphic undifferentiated sarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma

General Features.text: Localized, self-limited, benign, fibroosseous pseudotumor of digits or soft tissues; wide age range, mean: ~ 30 years
Size range: 2-12 cm (mean: 5 cm)
Radiologically and histologically classic zonation with cellular central area and peripheral ossification
Digital lesions may lack zonation
Central portion with myofibroblastic proliferation with active mitosis reminiscent of nodular fascitis
History of trauma in classic forms, but patient may not recollect trauma
M > F for soft tissue lesions, F > M for digital

Cytology.text: Plump stellate fibroblasts
Loose myxoid stroma with scattered lymphocytes and histiocytes;USP6gene rearrangement demonstrated by FISH
Differential diagnosis: Extraskeletal osteosarcoma, which lacks zonation and is markedly atypical

General Features.text: Benign, well-differentiated neoplasm containing ganglion cells and arising from sympathetic or peripheral nerves
Usually solitary, painless mass in posterior mediastinum or retroperitoneum, rarely adrenal and other locations
Age: 10-30 years

Cytology.text: Uniform tight bundles of spindle, nerve-like/Schwann cells with scattered large ganglion cells
Ganglion cells may contain fine cytoplasmic granular pigment
IHC: S100(+) in Schwann cells; synaptophysin (+) in ganglion cells
Differential diagnosis: Ganglioneuroblastoma: Younger age and contains immature neuroblasts; neurofibroma and schwannoma, which lack ganglion cells

General Features.text: Performed for diagnosis of systemic amyloidosis
Fastest and least expensive means of arriving at diagnosis
Sensitivity: Low (19-70%); specificity: Close to 100%
If positive, then speciation by immunohistochemistry or mass spectrometry is crucial for management

Cytology.text: Fat pad aspiration between umbilicus and symphysis pubis is performed using 21-gauge needle
Smears on frosted slides and cell block should be prepared
Alkaline Congo red stain on smears and cell block
Congophilia with apple-green birefringence is diagnostic
Alternatively, electron microscopy can be performed for diagnosis and is thought by some to be more sensitive
Congophilia should follow contours of adipocytes or around blood vessels
Apple-green birefringence should be fine and in same pattern as congophilia
